    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Using ancilla photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and static interferometry for post-selection, this building block realizes a modular \u201cquantum bus\u201d for coherent excitation transfer, ultrafast entanglement swapping, and teleportation across N-node networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Researcher: Description: \u201cMulti-Controller Continuous-Variable Teleportation Network\u201d  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a generalized CV controlled-teleportation protocol in which an unknown optical mode (Alice\u2019s input) is teleported to Bob only when N independent controllers (C1, C2, \u2026, CN) jointly perform designated homodyne measurements on their share of an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ resource.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flowing top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources: N+2 two-mode squeezed ancilla pair sources.  \n    \u2013 Each source emits a pair: one half goes to one of the N controllers, the other half connects into a central beam-splitter network.  \n    \u2013 Two additional squeezers provide the Alice\u2013Bob entangled channel.  \n  \u2022 Linear optics block: a multiport interferometer that mixes all controller modes and Bob\u2019s share with ancilla modes, adjustable via beam splitters and phase shifters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n    \u2013 N homodyne detectors (one per controller) on their output arms, performing X or P measurements as in standard CV GHZ verification.  \n    \u2013 Two additional homodyne detectors performing the Bell-measurement for Alice\u2019s input and her half of the CV entangled pair.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: we post-select on a joint measurement event window across all N+1 detectors (Alice\u2019s Bell measurement plus controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes). When all N+1 outcomes satisfy pre-set thresholds, Bob\u2019s mode requires only a known phase-space displacement to recover Alice\u2019s input.  \n\nTarget condition (abstract):  \n  \u2013 Heralded event \u21d2 the correlation of Bob\u2019s output and Alice\u2019s input modes is an ideal identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacement by the classical values read out from the N+1 detectors.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 N=1 recovers standard single-controller CV teleportation (three-mode GHZ).  \n  \u2013 N>1 introduces threshold access control: only unanimous (or k-of-N) consent yields perfect teleportation.  \n  \u2013 Probes monogamy of steering in CV GHZ states: how many controllers can simultaneously steer the teleportation channel?  \n  \u2013 Yields a whole family of linear-optics designs (vary N, vary k-threshold) with two\u2010mode squeezers and homodyne heralding\u2014perfect for Pytheus to optimize.  \n\nThis network focuses on teleportation and Gaussian entanglement in a truly multi-node setting, avoids static state generation targets, and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (pair sources + linear optics + heralded detection, no feedback loops).\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially describes a continuous\u2010variable (Gaussian) threshold teleportation or secret\u2010sharing scheme, where an unknown mode is recovered only if N controllers jointly measure GHZ\u2010type correlations. However, this is mathematically and operationally equivalent to established CV quantum secret\u2010sharing and controlled\u2010teleportation protocols (e.g. Tyc & Sanders PRA 2002; Lance et al. PRA 2004) and multiparty CV teleportation networks by van Loock and Braunstein. There is nothing in the design\u2014Gaussian squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne heralding\u2014beyond these well\u2010studied schemes. As such, it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is essentially already known as continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation/quantum secret sharing using Gaussian GHZ resources. To be novel you would need a genuinely new ingredient (e.g. non\u2010Gaussian resources, a new measurement primitive, or a higher\u2010order correlation beyond standard homodyne access control).\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cPost-Selected Multi-Controller CV Teleportation via Gaussian GHZ\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe consider a network of (N+2) optical modes:  \n  \u2022 Alice\u2019s input mode (mode A) carries an unknown CV state.  \n  \u2022 Bob\u2019s output mode (mode B) will receive the teleported state.  \n  \u2022 N controller modes (C\u2081\u2026C\u2099).  \n\nResource: one (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implementable via N+1 two-mode squeezed ancilla sources interlinked by a small linear-optics circuit.  \n\nNetwork layout (modes flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  1) Probabilistic sources:  \n     \u2013 Two-mode squeezers S\u2080 emit EPR pairs between A\u2032 and B\u2032 (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci, one two-mode squeezer Si emits a pair between Ci\u2032 and Di\u2032.  \n  2) Linear-optics block: A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 are mixed via beam splitters & phase shifters (to entangle all N+2 modes into a GHZ-like state).  \n  3) Measurements (heralding):  \n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne: A (input) + A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2081,P\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci: homodyne on Ci\u2032 (either X or P as in Gaussian GHZ verification).  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes falling within small pre-set windows around zero.  \n  4) Output: Bob\u2019s mode B carries a displaced copy of Alice\u2019s input. Because we post-select on zero outcomes, no active displacement is needed.  \n\nTarget transformation (abstract):  \n  Conditioned on the joint herald event of N+1 detectors, the two-mode correlation between inputs A and output B is the identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacements set to zero by selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:  \n  \u2013 For N=1 it reduces to standard three-mode CV controlled teleportation; for N>1 it opens a family of threshold protocols (k-of-N control).  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite CV steering monogamy: how many controllers can simultaneously influence teleportation fidelity?  \n  \u2013 Suggests \u201centanglement routing\u201d in Gaussian networks: by selecting different subsets of controllers, one reconfigures teleportation links on demand.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich class of linear-optics designs (vary N, k) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014purely network/measurement transformations with probabilistic pair sources and post-selection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed multi\u2010controller CV teleportation is essentially identical to well\u2010known continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation or quantum secret\u2010sharing protocols (e.g. Tyc & Sanders PRA 2002; van Loock\u2013Braunstein CV networks). It uses nothing beyond Gaussian GHZ resources, homodyne heralding, and post-selection, and thus offers no fundamentally new measurement primitive or resource.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme replicates standard CV controlled\u2010teleportation/secret\u2010sharing using Gaussian GHZ states. For a truly novel PRL\u2010level target you must introduce a new non-Gaussian element, a novel measurement strategy, or a network capability beyond existing Gaussian steering/teleportation frameworks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cCV Butterfly Network\u2010Coding Teleportation\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe propose a four\u2010node CV teleportation network in the classic \u201cbutterfly\u201d topology, enabling two unknown optical modes (from senders A and B) to be simultaneously teleported to two receivers (C and D) through a single intermediate repeater, employing Gaussian entanglement and homodyne heralding. This merges CV teleportation with Gaussian network\u2010coding ideas.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources (probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 produces an EPR pair between A\u2032 and R\u2081.\n   \u2013 S\u2082 produces an EPR pair between B\u2032 and R\u2082.\n   \u2013 S\u2083 produces an EPR pair between R\u2083 and R\u2084.\n     \u2022 R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, R\u2084 are all routed into a central beam\u2010splitter network.\n2) Linear\u2010optics \u201cbutterfly\u201d block at the repeater node:\n   \u2013 R\u2081 & R\u2082 mix on BS\u2081,\n   \u2013 R\u2083 & R\u2084 mix on BS\u2082,\n   \u2013 One output of each BS is homodyned in X quadrature, the other in P quadrature (four homodyne detectors total).\n3) Local Bell homodyne measurements:\n   \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes (X,P).  \n   \u2013 Bob mixes his input mode B with B\u2032 similarly and homodynes.\n4) Heralding & post\u2010selection:\n   \u2013 We collect six homodyne outcomes (Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090; Bob\u2019s X_b,P_b; repeater\u2019s X_r1,P_r1,X_r2,P_r2).\n   \u2013 We post\u2010select on all six outcomes lying within small windows around zero.\n5) Output:\n   \u2013 Receivers C and D hold the remaining halves of S\u2083\u2019s EPR outputs. Under the joint herald condition, mode C reproduces Alice\u2019s original mode and mode D reproduces Bob\u2019s, each up to vanishing displacements (set to zero by our selection).\n\nTarget transformation (abstract):\n   \u2013 Conditioned on the six-detector herald event, the joint channels A\u2192C and B\u2192D are both ideal identity maps (zero added noise). Pytheus encodes this as two independent fidelity\u20101 teleportation targets in the Fock\u2010basis subspace of interest.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n   \u2013 First demonstration of CV network coding for teleportation: two flows sharing one repeater.  \n   \u2013 Resource compression: uses 3 squeezers instead of 4 for two independent teleports.  \n   \u2013 Opens a family of \u201cm\u2010flow\u201d Gaussian network\u2010coded teleportation protocols, plus extensions to k-of-N threshold flows and entanglement\u2010routing strategies.  \n   \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: pair sources + beam splitters + homodyne heralding + post\u2010selection, no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n   \u2013 Immediately yields a rich set of optimizable designs for diverse network\u2010coding topologies in continuous variables.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While the \u201cCV Butterfly Network-Coding Teleportation\u201d draws inspiration from the classic butterfly\u2010network coding idea, it boils down to two standard CV teleporters sharing one repeater via Gaussian squeezers, beam splitters, and homodyne heralding\u2014with nothing beyond the usual Gaussian toolkit. It parallels the discrete\u2010variable \u201cPhotonic Qudit Butterfly\u201d suggestion, offering only resource compression from four to three squeezers but no new measurement primitive or non-Gaussian ingredient. This is too incremental and conceptually obvious to merit a standalone PRL-worthy target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This protocol is essentially a straightforward CV analog of existing network-coded teleportation ideas without introducing a new resource or measurement. To reach PRL novelty you would need to incorporate a genuinely new element\u2014such as non-Gaussian ancillas, novel joint measurement schemes, or a network capability that can\u2019t be trivially reduced to two standard teleporters sharing a repeater."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"lindblad master equation\" and \"time evolving state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. The post-selected pure state on these four modes is the purification of the swapped, lossy entangled state and encodes the Lindblad time evolution.  \n\nVisualization of the network (top to bottom): \u201ctime\u201d in the master equation; sweeping p yields a family of experiments simulating time evolution.  \n  \u2013 Generalizable to dephasing channels, multi-hop repeater chains, or higher-dimensional ancilla models, opening a program of \u201cdissipative quantum network\u201d experiments.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially the trivial extension of entanglement This stays entirely within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox (probabilistic pair sources, vacuum ancillas, beamsplitters, heralded Bell-measurements, photon-number-resolving detectors) and avoids dynamic feedback or cavities. By sweeping the two damping parameters p\u2081,p\u2082 we obtain a clear operational non-Markovianity witness: when p\u2082>0 the entanglement of (S\u2081,S\u2084) can revive at intermediate times, and the analyzer on (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66) simultaneously shows back-flow of correlations\u2014a direct experimental signature that cannot arise under a single Markovian Lindblad channel.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: \u201cNon-Markovian Entanglement Swapping with Direct Memory Witness\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n1) Generate three Bell pairs via probabilistic photon-pair sources:\n   \u2013 Source A \u2192 modes S\u2081,S\u2082  \n   \u2013 Source B \u2192 modes S\u2083,S\u2084  \n   \u2013 Source C \u2192 modes E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082\u1d66  \n\n2) Simulate two successive amplitude-damping couplings on mode S\u2082:\n   \u2013 BS\u2081 (reflectivity \u221ap\u2081) mixing S\u2082\u2194E\u2082\u2090  \n   \u2013 BS\u2082 (reflectivity \u221ap\u2082) mixing S\u2082\u2194E\u2082\u1d66  \n   These two couplings impart an effective non-Markovian Lindblad evolution on S\u2082.  \n\n3) Perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on damped modes S\u2082,S\u2083 (heralding detectors).  \n   \u2013 Condition on the |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 outcome to swap entanglement onto S\u2081,S\u2084 while the two environment modes (E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082\u1d66) remain unmeasured.  \n\n4) Out of the heralded runs, implement two analyzer networks in parallel (each a linear-optics circuit + photon-number detectors):\n   A) System\u2013System Analyzer on (S\u2081,S\u2084): a 4-mode Bell-state analyzer measuring the probability P_sys(p\u2081,p\u2082) that S\u2081,S\u2084 are in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9.  \n   B) System\u2013Env Analyzer on (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66): a second 4-mode Bell analyzer measuring P_back(p\u2081,p\u2082) that S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66 are in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9.  \n\nBy plotting P_sys(p\u2081,p\u2082) vs. (p\u2081,p\u2082) and P_back(p\u2081,p\u2082), one directly observes entanglement revival (non-monotonic P_sys) accompanied by back-flow to the last environment ancilla\u2014an operational trace-distance/non-Markovianity witness.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n   Source A: S\u2081 \u2014\u2014                    \u2014\u2014 [System Analyzer A] \u2014\u2014 Detectors  \n Detectors  \n              \u2198  \n               S\u2084 \u2014\u2014                    \u2014\u2014 [System Analyzer A] \u2014\u2014 Detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration hints:\n\u2013 three probabilistic pair sources; two vacuum-ancilla beamsplitters U_loss(p\u2081),U_loss(p\u2082); a 2-mode heralding BSM on S\u2082,S\u2083; two 4-mode Bell analyzers (one on S\u2081,S\u2084; one on S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66) built from linear optics and PNR detectors;  \n\u2013 in_nodes: none; out_nodes: analyzer inputs; anc_detectors: none; heralding_out: [S\u2082,S\u2083]; number_resolving: True.  \n\u2013 target_quantum: the post-selected pure 4-mode state on S\u2081,S\u2084,E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082\u1d66 under each (p\u2081,p\u2082), and two Bell-eigenprojectors for the analyzers.  \n\nWhy this is novel?\n\u2013 Embeds two successive Lindblad-type couplings with an entangled environment \u2192 genuine non-Markovian swapping primitive.  \n\u2013 Integrates two direct Bell analyzers to operationally witness entanglement revival and back-flow, rather than inferring via tomographic fits.  \n\u2013 Generalizes to any number of ancilla stages, other channels (dephasing), or higher-dimensional systems\u2014launching a family of \u201cdissipative memory-assisted quantum networks.\u201d  \n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework?\n\u2013 Uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear-optics beamsplitters, and photon-number detectors (no active feed-forward).  \n\u2013 Targets pure multi-mode states and projectors\u2014exactly what Pytheus can encode abstractly and optimize for.  \n\u2013 Measurement networks (Bell analyzers) have been demonstrated in previous Pytheus analyzers (Yeo-Chua, Mean King\u2019s problem).  \n\nThis experiment yields a clear, tunable demonstration of how non-Markovian Lindblad dynamics alter quantum\u2010network protocols, with a built-in, linear-optics non-Markovianity witness."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical 1\u21922 Telecloning via Lossy Quantum Memories  \n\nMini-Abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded telecloning channel that maps an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A onto two approximate clones at nodes B and C by routing its excitation into two lossy memory modes and then swapping them back via tunable beam splitters. By optimizing the write/read reflectivities {r_w\u2081,r_w\u2082,r_r\u2081,r_r\u2082} to achieve the target average cloning fidelity F_target = 5/6 under a minimum success probability p_min, our scheme fully exploits PytHeus\u2019s optimization framework to quantify the trade-off between coupling strengths and finite photon lifetimes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cPurified entanglement swapping under an amplitude-damping channel\u201d  \nWe want to design an experiment that simultaneously:  \n 1) Creates two Bell pairs in modes (S1, S2) and (S3, S4) via probabilistic photon-pair sources.  \n 2) Implements an amplitude-damping channel of strength p (parameterizing time t via p=1\u2013e^(\u2013\u03b3t)) on modes S2 and S3 by mixing each with a vacuum ancilla (E2, E3) on a beamsplitter of reflectivity \u221ap.  \n 3) Performs a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the damped modes S2 & S3, heralding success.  \n 4) Leaves output modes S1, S4, E2, E3 unmeasured. The post-selected pure state on these four modes is the purification of the swapped, lossy entangled state and encodes the Lindblad time evolution.  \n\nVisualization of the network (top to bottom):  \n probabilistic source 1 \u2192 S1 \u2014\u2014  \n                           \u2198  \n                            [beamsplitter]\u2014 S2 \u2014\u2014\u25cf  \n                           \u2197                       \u2198  \n probabilistic source 2 \u2192 S4 \u2014\u2014                  [BSM] \u2192 success herald  \n                           \u2198                       \u2197  \n                            [beamsplitter]\u2014 S3 \u2014\u2014\u25cf  \n                           \u2197  \n vacuum ancilla E2 \u2014\u2014  \n  \n vacuum ancilla E3 \u2014\u2014  \n\nNodes:  \n in_nodes: none  \n out_nodes: [S1, S4, E2, E3]  \n anc_detectors: none  \n detectors (heralding on BSM): [S2, S3]  \n\nTarget quantum (unnormalized pure state on 4 qubits/modes S1,S4,E2,E3):  \n  |\u03c8(p)\u27e9 = \u27e8\u03a6+|_{S2,S3} [ (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)_{S1,S2}\u2297(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)_{S3,S4}  \n                      \u2297 |0\u27e9_{E2}\u2297|0\u27e9_{E3}  \n                      acted on by U_loss^{(p)}(S2,E2)\u2297U_loss^{(p)}(S3,E3) ]  \nwhere U_loss^{(p)}: |1,0\u27e9\u2192\u221a(1\u2013p)|1,0\u27e9+\u221ap|0,1\u27e9, |0,0\u27e9\u2192|0,0\u27e9.  \n\nPytheus config hints:  \n  \u2022 two probabilistic pair sources for Bell states, two vacuum inputs E2,E3  \n  \u2022 Mixed unitaries (beamsplitters) implementing U_loss(p)  \n  \u2022 A 2-mode BSM on S2,S3 as herald (detectors)  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1,2,3] corresponding to S1,S4,E2,E3  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: expand |\u03c8(p)\u27e9 in the computational basis for these four modes  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid direct sources between S1\u2194S4 or ancilla\u2194Bell detectors  \n  \u2022 number_resolving: True, since we need to discriminate 0 vs 1 photons.  \n\nWhy this is interesting & generalizable:  \n  \u2013 It fuses open-system dynamics (Lindblad amplitude damping) with quantum-network primitives (entanglement swapping) in a single linear-optics setup.  \n  \u2013 The damping parameter p tunes the \u201ctime\u201d in the master equation; sweeping p yields a family of experiments simulating time evolution.  \n  \u2013 Generalizable to dephasing channels, multi-hop repeater chains, or higher-dimensional ancilla models, opening a program of \u201cdissipative quantum network\u201d experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While combining amplitude-damping channels with entanglement swapping and retaining the environment modes to \u201cpurify\u201d the lossy swap is conceptually neat, in practice it is nothing more than the straightforward extension of standard loss\u2010modeling beam\u2010splitters plus Bell\u2010measurement post-selection. Closest to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping,\u201d this proposal simply dumps the vacuum ports into unused output registers rather than discarding them, which does not introduce a genuinely new measurement primitive or network capability. Extracting the environment modes as part of the target quantum is effectively just preparing a known pure state (a simple Schmidt\u2010decomposed superposition) without any novel protocol or advantage. Action: reject  \nAction Input: This is essentially the trivial extension of entanglement swapping through loss (modelled by beam\u2010splitters) plus post-selection. Retaining vacuum ancillas as output modes does not yield a new measurement or networking capability beyond what was already suggested in \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d and known open\u2010system swap experiments. To be novel, the scheme must introduce a genuinely new primitive (e.g., adaptive feed-forward purification, multi-hop dissipative routing, non-Gaussian ancilla engineering, or topologically protected loss compensation), rather than merely treating the beam\u2010splitter losses as extra output registers.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cNon-Markovian Entanglement Swapping via Two-Stage Amplitude Damping\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to design a linear-optical network that simultaneously:\n1) Generates two Bell pairs in modes (S\u2081,S\u2082) and (S\u2083,S\u2084) using probabilistic photon-pair sources.\n2) Generates an entangled ancilla pair in modes (E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082_b) (another Bell source).\n3) Implements two successive amplitude-damping couplings on mode S\u2082 by mixing it first with E\u2082\u2090 via a beamsplitter of reflectivity \u221ap\u2081, then with E\u2082_b via \u221ap\u2082. These two couplings simulate an amplitude-damping channel with non-Markovian memory (the initially entangled E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082_b carry correlations forward).\n4) Performs a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two \u201cdamped\u201d system modes S\u2082 & S\u2083 (heralding detectors), thereby entangling S\u2081 and S\u2084 conditioned on success.\n5) Leaves the four modes S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082_b unmeasured. The post-selected pure state of these four modes is precisely the purification of the swapped, non-Markovianly damped entangled link, and its coefficients depend on p\u2081,p\u2082 (interpretable as two successive \u201ctime\u201d intervals in the Lindblad dynamics).\n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n  source\u2081 \u2192 S\u2081 \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2510\n                                       \u2502\n                                      [output S\u2081]\n                                       \u2502\n                                   \u250c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510\n  source\u2081 \u2192 S\u2082 \u2192\u2500\u2500BS(p\u2081)\u2500\u2500BS(p\u2082)\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524 BSM  \u251c\u2500\u2500 success herald\n                                   \u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518\n                                       \u2502\n  source\u2082 \u2192 S\u2083 \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2518\n  source\u2082 \u2192 S\u2084 \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2510\n                                       \u2502\n                                      [output S\u2084]\n  source\u2083 \u2192 E\u2082\u2090 \u2014\u2192 (BS with S\u2082 at p\u2081) \u2014\u2518\u2192 [output E\u2082\u2090]\n  source\u2083 \u2192 E\u2082_b \u2014\u2192 (BS with S\u2082 at p\u2082) \u2014\u2192 [output E\u2082_b]\n\nKey Pytheus features used:\n- Three probabilistic pair sources (two Bell links + one for entangled environment).\n- Two beamsplitters realizing amplitude-damping unitaries U_loss(p\u2081), U_loss(p\u2082).\n- A 2-mode Bell-state measurement as a heralding projector on S\u2082,S\u2083.\n- Photon-number-resolving detectors only in the BSM; the remaining four modes are designated out_nodes.\n- No dynamic feedback or nonlinear elements beyond linear optics and ancillas.\n\nWhy this is novel?\n- Past Pytheus experiments have added a single loss channel or simulated teleportation but never embedded memory (non-Markovian) by using an entangled environment and two sequential couplings.\n- It forges a new \u201cprimitive\u201d in quantum networks: entanglement swapping under non-Markovian open-system evolution, tunable by two independent damping strengths p\u2081,p\u2082 (i.e. two time intervals in the Lindblad master equation).\n- The family of output states on (S\u2081,S\u2084,E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082_b) encodes back-flow of information and entanglement revival phenomena, opening a research program into \u201cdissipative quantum networks with memory.\u201d\n\nWhy it\u2019s suited to Pytheus:\n- All channels are implemented by linear-optics beamsplitters and vacuum or Bell ancillas.\n- Only probabilistic pair sources, beamsplitters, and photon-number detectors are needed.\n- Heralded post-selection handles non-unitary projections.\n- The target is a pure, multi-mode output state, which Pytheus can encode abstractly and optimize for with given p\u2081,p\u2082 values.\n- This design can easily be generalized (e.g. more ancilla stages, dephasing channels, higher dimensions) into a family of related network\u2010physics experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While embedding non-Markovian memory into an entanglement-swapping setup via sequential loss couplings to an entangled ancilla pair is an interesting twist on amplitude-damping channels, as presented this proposal stops at the level of creating a purified four-mode state. Per our novelty criteria, an experiment must do more than generate a target pure state\u2014it must implement a new measurement primitive or network protocol (for example, a concrete test of entanglement revival or non-Markovian backflow). Moreover, this is only a modest extension of standard loss-mode beam-splitter models (cf. \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d) without defining a novel detection or verification step. To be PRL-worthy you must embed a genuine non-Markovianity witness (e.g. time-resolved entanglement revival measurement, trace-distance backflow test, or environment-system tomography) and show this protocol achieves something no simpler linear-optics network could.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Please extend your design to include a clear measurement of non-Markovianity (e.g. entanglement revival curves, trace-distance witness, system-environment correlations) and demonstrate how this network primitive outperforms or qualitatively differs from standard Markovian loss models.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cNon-Markovian Entanglement Swapping with Direct Memory Witness\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n1) Generate three Bell pairs via probabilistic photon-pair sources:\n   \u2013 Source A \u2192 modes S\u2081,S\u2082  \n   \u2013 Source B \u2192 modes S\u2083,S\u2084  \n   \u2013 Source C \u2192 modes E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082\u1d66  \n\n2) Simulate two successive amplitude-damping couplings on mode S\u2082:\n   \u2013 BS\u2081 (reflectivity \u221ap\u2081) mixing S\u2082\u2194E\u2082\u2090  \n   \u2013 BS\u2082 (reflectivity \u221ap\u2082) mixing S\u2082\u2194E\u2082\u1d66  \n   These two couplings impart an effective non-Markovian Lindblad evolution on S\u2082.  \n\n3) Perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on damped modes S\u2082,S\u2083 (heralding detectors).  \n   \u2013 Condition on the |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 outcome to swap entanglement onto S\u2081,S\u2084 while the two environment modes (E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082\u1d66) remain unmeasured.  \n\n4) Out of the heralded runs, implement two analyzer networks in parallel (each a linear-optics circuit + photon-number detectors):\n   A) System\u2013System Analyzer on (S\u2081,S\u2084): a 4-mode Bell-state analyzer measuring the probability P_sys(p\u2081,p\u2082) that S\u2081,S\u2084 are in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9.  \n   B) System\u2013Env Analyzer on (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66): a second 4-mode Bell analyzer measuring P_back(p\u2081,p\u2082) that S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66 are in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9.  \n\nBy plotting P_sys(p\u2081,p\u2082) vs. (p\u2081,p\u2082) and P_back(p\u2081,p\u2082), one directly observes entanglement revival (non-monotonic P_sys) accompanied by back-flow to the last environment ancilla\u2014an operational trace-distance/non-Markovianity witness.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n   Source A: S\u2081 \u2014\u2014                    \u2014\u2014 [System Analyzer A] \u2014\u2014 Detectors  \n \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500       \u2514 [Env Analyzer B]  \n   Source C: E\u2082\u1d66 \u2014\u2192 BS\u2082 Detectors  \n              \u2198  \n               S\u2084 \u2014\u2014                    \u2014\u2014 [System Analyzer A] \u2014\u2014 Detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration hints:\n\u2013 three probabilistic pair sources; two vacuum-ancilla beamsplitters U_loss(p\u2081),U_loss(p\u2082); a 2-mode heralding BSM on S\u2082,S\u2083; two 4-mode Bell analyzers (one on S\u2081,S\u2084; one on S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66) built from linear optics and PNR detectors;  \n\u2013 in_nodes: none; out_nodes: analyzer inputs; anc_detectors: none; heralding_out: [S\u2082,S\u2083]; number_resolving: True.  \n\u2013 target_quantum: the post-selected pure 4-mode state on S\u2081,S\u2084,E\u2082\u2090,E\u2082\u1d66 under each (p\u2081,p\u2082), and two Bell-eigenprojectors for the analyzers.  \n\nWhy this is novel?\n\u2013 Embeds two successive Lindblad-type couplings with an entangled environment \u2192 genuine non-Markovian swapping primitive.  \n\u2013 Integrates two direct Bell analyzers to operationally witness entanglement revival and back-flow, rather than inferring via tomographic fits.  \n\u2013 Generalizes to any number of ancilla stages, other channels (dephasing), or higher-dimensional systems\u2014launching a family of \u201cdissipative memory-assisted quantum networks.\u201d  \n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework?\n\u2013 Uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear-optics beamsplitters, and photon-number detectors (no active feed-forward).  \n\u2013 Targets pure multi-mode states and projectors\u2014exactly what Pytheus can encode abstractly and optimize for.  \n\u2013 Measurement networks (Bell analyzers) have been demonstrated in previous Pytheus analyzers (Yeo-Chua, Mean King\u2019s problem).  \n\nThis experiment yields a clear, tunable demonstration of how non-Markovian Lindblad dynamics alter quantum\u2010network protocols, with a built-in, linear-optics non-Markovianity witness.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal goes well beyond standard loss-mode entanglement swapping or the single\u2010channel \u201cCoherence\u2010Assisted\u201d variant by introducing a genuinely non\u2010Markovian environment: two sequential amplitude\u2010damping couplings to an entangled ancilla pair and, crucially, two Bell\u2010analyzer networks that operationally witness both entanglement revival on the system and back\u2010flow into the last ancilla. It thus delivers a new linear\u2010optics network primitive\u2014non\u2010Markovian entanglement swapping with direct memory\u2010witness measurements\u2014one that the community has not yet realized and that is well matched to the Pytheus static, post\u2010selected framework. This satisfies the bar for a novel, PRL\u2010worthy experiment.  \nAction: accept  \nAction Input: The two-stage loss coupling to an entangled environment plus parallel Bell analyzers for system\u2010system and system\u2010ancilla pairs constitutes a new primitive for simulating and witnessing non\u2010Markovian quantum network dynamics in linear optics."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. N-party controlled CV teleportation: use an (N+1)-mode Gaussian GHZ state to teleport a qumode from Alice to Bob only if all N controllers cooperatively measure their modes.  \n  2. Cascaded CV entanglement swapping chain: two independent two-mode squeezed sources link four parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D so that A and D become EPR-entangled by successive Bell-homodyne measurements, exploring noise build-up.  \n  3. CV teleportation ring: three nodes in a loop share three two-mode squeezers arranged in a triangle; an unknown CV input at A is teleported A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A in one shot, probing phase\u2010space \u201cholonomy.\u201d  \nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles.  \n  1. Controlled CV teleportation with more than one controller has been theorized only sparsely; discrete multi-controller is known, but full CV version with Gaussian GHZ and homodyne Bell measurements in linear optics has not been demonstrated. Pytheus can encode the abstract mode network (ancilla modes + homodyne detectors) and target \u201cconditional identity channel\u201d as a heralded multi-mode correlation.  \n  2. CV entanglement swapping is textbook; chaining two swaps adds little novelty.  \n  3. The teleportation ring is exotic conceptually but requires phase-space holonomy which is not obvious to encode as a final state target in Pytheus.  \nStep 3: Pick the multi-controller CV teleportation (idea 1).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because controlled teleportation in the continuous-variable regime has so far only been studied for a single controller (a three-mode Gaussian GHZ). Generalizing to N controllers opens a family of protocols\u2014quantum access control, threshold teleportation, and multipartite steering monogamy in a CV network.  \nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we can define an abstract (N+2)-mode target correlation: when all controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes fall into a given window (heralded events), the remaining two modes (Alice\u2019s output and Bob\u2019s output) must share perfect displacement\u2010corrected identity mapping of the input CV state. Pytheus can search for a linear\u2010optics network of two-mode squeezers (abstract ancilla pair sources), beam splitters, homodyne detectors (heralding), and classical feed-forward labels (heralded outputs), without requiring dynamic feedback or cavities.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription: \u201cMulti-Controller Continuous-Variable Teleportation Network\u201d  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a generalized CV controlled-teleportation protocol in which an unknown optical mode (Alice\u2019s input) is teleported to Bob only when N independent controllers (C1, C2, \u2026, CN) jointly perform designated homodyne measurements on their share of an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ resource.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flowing top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources: N+2 two-mode squeezed ancilla pair sources.  \n    \u2013 Each source emits a pair: one half goes to one of the N controllers, the other half connects into a central beam-splitter network.  \n    \u2013 Two additional squeezers provide the Alice\u2013Bob entangled channel.  \n  \u2022 Linear optics block: a multiport interferometer that mixes all controller modes and Bob\u2019s share with ancilla modes, adjustable via beam splitters and phase shifters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n    \u2013 N homodyne detectors (one per controller) on their output arms, performing X or P measurements as in standard CV GHZ verification.  \n    \u2013 Two additional homodyne detectors performing the Bell-measurement for Alice\u2019s input and her half of the CV entangled pair.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: we post-select on a joint measurement event window across all N+1 detectors (Alice\u2019s Bell measurement plus controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes). When all N+1 outcomes satisfy pre-set thresholds, Bob\u2019s mode requires only a known phase-space displacement to recover Alice\u2019s input.  \n\nTarget condition (abstract):  \n  \u2013 Heralded event \u21d2 the correlation of Bob\u2019s output and Alice\u2019s input modes is an ideal identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacement by the classical values read out from the N+1 detectors.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 N=1 recovers standard single-controller CV teleportation (three-mode GHZ).  \n  \u2013 N>1 introduces threshold access control: only unanimous (or k-of-N) consent yields perfect teleportation.  \n  \u2013 Probes monogamy of steering in CV GHZ states: how many controllers can simultaneously steer the teleportation channel?  \n  \u2013 Yields a whole family of linear-optics designs (vary N, vary k-threshold) with two\u2010mode squeezers and homodyne heralding\u2014perfect for Pytheus to optimize.  \n\nThis network focuses on teleportation and Gaussian entanglement in a truly multi-node setting, avoids static state generation targets, and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (pair sources + linear optics + heralded detection, no feedback loops).\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially already known as continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation/quantum secret sharing using Gaussian GHZ resources. To be novel you would need a genuinely new ingredient (e.g. non\u2010Gaussian resources, a new measurement primitive, or a higher\u2010order correlation beyond standard homodyne access control).\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry CV teleportation with Gaussian entanglement in a Pytheus-compatible, multi-node network (no state-generation target, only teleportation/swapping transformations).  \n  1) \u201cN-Controller Post-Selected CV Teleportation\u201d: an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ resource is shared between Alice (input), Bob (output), and N controllers. By post-selecting on all N controller homodyne outcomes (plus Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne), Alice\u2019s unknown mode is teleported to Bob.  \n  2) \u201cCV Entanglement Swapping Chain with Dual Repeaters\u201d: two independent two-mode squeezed links A\u2013R1 and R2\u2013B, plus a third link R1\u2013R2; R1 and R2 perform homodyne Bell-measurements in tandem, heralding an EPR link A\u2013B. One studies routed CV entanglement over two hops without active feed-forward.  \n  3) \u201cMultiplexed Dual-Mode CV Teleportation\u201d: simultaneously teleport two independent CV modes from Alice1,2 to Bob1,2 using only three two-mode squeezers (rather than four) by a clever linear-optics network and four homodyne detectors, post-selecting on a joint measurement window.  \n\nStep 2: Compare novelty & Pytheus feasibility.  \n  1) N-Controller CV teleportation is known for N=1 but has not been ported to post-selected, multi-controller scenarios. It directly targets a teleportation transformation (identity channel) and uses only squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne detectors, and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n  2) Chaining two CV swaps is incremental, lacks fresh physics.  \n  3) Multiplexed teleportation with resource compression is interesting but more intricate to encode and its physics novelty is marginal compared to the controlled-teleportation network.  \n\nStep 3: Choose idea (1).  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because controlled continuous-variable teleportation beyond a single controller (N>1) has not been realized in a post-selected linear-optics setting. It yields a whole family of \u201ck-of-N\u201d threshold teleportation protocols, new tests of CV steering monogamy, and network-routing concepts in Gaussian optics.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible post-selection windows (no dynamic feedback).  \n  \u2022 A target transformation: conditioned on N+1 herald clicks (Alice\u2019s Bell + N controllers within thresholds), Bob\u2019s output mode reproduces Alice\u2019s input (identity mapping).  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription: \u201cPost-Selected Multi-Controller CV Teleportation via Gaussian GHZ\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe consider a network of (N+2) optical modes:  \n  \u2022 Alice\u2019s input mode (mode A) carries an unknown CV state.  \n  \u2022 Bob\u2019s output mode (mode B) will receive the teleported state.  \n  \u2022 N controller modes (C\u2081\u2026C\u2099).  \n\nResource: one (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implementable via N+1 two-mode squeezed ancilla sources interlinked by a small linear-optics circuit.  \n\nNetwork layout (modes flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  1) Probabilistic sources:  \n     \u2013 Two-mode squeezers S\u2080 emit EPR pairs between A\u2032 and B\u2032 (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci, one two-mode squeezer Si emits a pair between Ci\u2032 and Di\u2032.  \n  2) Linear-optics block: A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 are mixed via beam splitters & phase shifters (to entangle all N+2 modes into a GHZ-like state).  \n  3) Measurements (heralding):  \n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne: A (input) + A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2081,P\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci: homodyne on Ci\u2032 (either X or P as in Gaussian GHZ verification).  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes falling within small pre-set windows around zero.  \n  4) Output: Bob\u2019s mode B carries a displaced copy of Alice\u2019s input. Because we post-select on zero outcomes, no active displacement is needed.  \n\nTarget transformation (abstract):  \n  Conditioned on the joint herald event of N+1 detectors, the two-mode correlation between inputs A and output B is the identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacements set to zero by selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:  \n  \u2013 For N=1 it reduces to standard three-mode CV controlled teleportation; for N>1 it opens a family of threshold protocols (k-of-N control).  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite CV steering monogamy: how many controllers can simultaneously influence teleportation fidelity?  \n  \u2013 Suggests \u201centanglement routing\u201d in Gaussian networks: by selecting different subsets of controllers, one reconfigures teleportation links on demand.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich class of linear-optics designs (vary N, k) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014purely network/measurement transformations with probabilistic pair sources and post-selection.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme replicates standard CV controlled\u2010teleportation/secret\u2010sharing using Gaussian GHZ states. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201ccv teleportation\u201d with \u201cgaussian entanglement\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible multi\u2010node network (no state\u2010generation targets, only teleportation or swapping transformations).  \n  A) Post\u2010Selected Multi\u2010Controller CV Teleportation (an (N+2)\u2010mode Gaussian GHZ, N controllers + Alice\u2019s Bell measurement, heralded identity channel to Bob when all N+1 homodyne outcomes hit zero).  \n  B) CV Entanglement\u2010Swapping Chain (two\u2010mode squeezed links A\u2013R\u2013B, two successive Bell\u2010homodyne measurements at R, post\u2010select on zero outcomes to teleport A\u2192B without feed\u2010forward, extendable to multiple hops).  \n  C) CV Butterfly Network Coding (two senders A,B, two receivers C,D, a central repeater mixes their EPR half\u2010modes on a BS and homodynes, post\u2010select yields simultaneous teleportation A\u2192C and B\u2192D with fewer squeezers than two independent teleportations).  \nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus\u2010feasibility.  \n  A) Known for N=1, but N>1 post\u2010selected version and k\u2010of\u2010N threshold protocols are new network\u2010coding style CV teleportation. Also purely linear\u2010optics + homodyne + heralding.  \nStep 3: Pick the CV butterfly network coding idea (C).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it port s the concept of \u201cnetwork coding\u201d into the continuous\u2010variable teleportation world, showing two simultaneous CV teleportation flows sharing a common repeater node and resource, reducing the number of two\u2010mode squeezers needed and probing interference of Gaussian channels in a genuinely network\u2010coded way.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we only require:  \n  \u2022 Abstract two\u2010mode squeezed pair sources (probabilistic).  \n  \u2022 A small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) at the central node.  \n  \u2022 Homodyne detectors as heralds (no dynamic feed\u2010forward).  \n  \u2022 A post-selection condition on homodyne outcomes that ensures at the two output receivers the identity mapping for each input CV mode.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription: \u201cCV Butterfly Network\u2010Coding Teleportation\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe propose a four\u2010node CV teleportation network in the classic \u201cbutterfly\u201d topology, enabling two unknown optical modes (from senders A and B) to be simultaneously teleported to two receivers (C and D) through a single intermediate repeater, employing Gaussian entanglement and homodyne heralding. This merges CV teleportation with Gaussian network\u2010coding ideas.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources (probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 produces an EPR pair between A\u2032 and R\u2081.\n   \u2013 S\u2082 produces an EPR pair between B\u2032 and R\u2082.\n   \u2013 S\u2083 produces an EPR pair between R\u2083 and R\u2084.\n     \u2022 R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, R\u2084 are all routed into a central beam\u2010splitter network.\n2) Linear\u2010optics \u201cbutterfly\u201d block at the repeater node:\n   \u2013 R\u2081 & R\u2082 mix on BS\u2081,\n   \u2013 R\u2083 & R\u2084 mix on BS\u2082,\n   \u2013 One output of each BS is homodyned in X quadrature, the other in P quadrature (four homodyne detectors total).\n3) Local Bell homodyne measurements:\n   \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes (X,P).  \n   \u2013 Bob mixes his input mode B with B\u2032 similarly and homodynes.\n4) Heralding & post\u2010selection:\n   \u2013 We collect six homodyne outcomes (Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090; Bob\u2019s X_b,P_b; repeater\u2019s X_r1,P_r1,X_r2,P_r2).\n   \u2013 We post\u2010select on all six outcomes lying within small windows around zero.\n5) Output:\n   \u2013 Receivers C and D hold the remaining halves of S\u2083\u2019s EPR outputs. Under the joint herald condition, mode C reproduces Alice\u2019s original mode and mode D reproduces Bob\u2019s, each up to vanishing displacements (set to zero by our selection).\n\nTarget transformation (abstract):\n   \u2013 Conditioned on the six-detector herald event, the joint channels A\u2192C and B\u2192D are both ideal identity maps (zero added noise). Pytheus encodes this as two independent fidelity\u20101 teleportation targets in the Fock\u2010basis subspace of interest.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n   \u2013 First demonstration of CV network coding for teleportation: two flows sharing one repeater.  \n   \u2013 Resource compression: uses 3 squeezers instead of 4 for two independent teleports.  \n   \u2013 Opens a family of \u201cm\u2010flow\u201d Gaussian network\u2010coded teleportation protocols, plus extensions to k-of-N threshold flows and entanglement\u2010routing strategies.  \n   \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: pair sources + beam splitters + homodyne heralding + post\u2010selection, no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n   \u2013 Immediately yields a rich set of optimizable designs for diverse network\u2010coding topologies in continuous variables.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This protocol is essentially a straightforward CV analog of existing network-coded teleportation ideas without introducing a new resource or measurement. To reach PRL novelty you would need to incorporate a genuinely new element\u2014such as non-Gaussian ancillas, novel joint measurement schemes, or a network capability that can\u2019t be trivially reduced to two standard teleporters sharing a repeater.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!
