Pytheus can do it but not novel.\n  2) Close to independent teleporters \u2013 novelty low.\n  3) Cluster-based teleportation routing has not been demonstrated in CV experiments without active feed-forward. It genuinely combines Gaussian entanglement (cluster resource) and CV teleportation in a network-routing context. Pytheus can optimize a network of squeezers, beam splitters, and homodyne detectors with post-selection\u2014no feedback loops or cavities needed.\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\nStep 4: Novelty:  \n  \u2013 Introduces the first \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d network that uses a small Gaussian cluster state as a switch: by choosing which intermediate cluster node(s) to homodyne and post-selecting on zero outcomes, one routes an unknown CV mode from any input leaf to any desired output leaf.  \n  \u2013 Opens a broad family of CV entanglement-routing protocols: star, tree, ring, where measurement patterns alone steer the teleportation path.  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of measurement-based CV network control in a static linear-optics layout.\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n  \u2013 Only uses abstract two-mode squeezers (probabilistic pair sources), a static interferometer of beam splitters & phase shifters to build the cluster, and homodyne detectors as heralds (ancilla detectors) with post-selection windows.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement \u2014 all within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cPassive CV Teleportation Router via a Gaussian Star-Cluster State\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a small measurement-based continuous-variable (CV) teleportation network that acts as a passive \u201crouter,\u201d directing an unknown input mode from any chosen input port (leaf) to any selected output port (leaf) solely by the choice of homodyne measurements on intermediate cluster nodes. The resource is a simple star-shaped CV cluster state (Gaussian entanglement), generated by two-mode squeezers and beam splitters. No active displacements or feed-forward control is required: we post-select on homodyne outcomes near zero to effect perfect teleportation along the selected branch.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 For each of M leaves (ports) we have one two-mode squeezer that emits an EPR pair between leaf mode Li\u2032 and its corresponding cluster hub mode Hi.  \n     \u2013 The M hub modes H1\u2026HM are then mixed pairwise on a small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to create the star-cluster entanglement across all M+1 modes (the +1 is the central cluster node where all Hi meet).\n  2) Input coupling:\n     \u2013 An unknown CV mode A (sitting at leaf Lk) is coupled by a 50:50 beam splitter to its ancilla squeezed half Lk\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation measurements:\n     \u2013 We homodyne both outputs of that 50:50 BS in X and P quadratures\u2014call these detectors BX,BP.  \n     \u2013 We then homodyne all hub modes Hi except the one leading to the desired output leaf Lj in a fixed quadrature (e.g. X). By selecting which Hi not to measure, we choose the output port.  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 We accept only events where all homodyne outcomes (BX\u22480, BP\u22480, and the M\u20131 hub homodyne results \u22480) lie within small preset windows.  \n     \u2013 Under this collective herald, the unmeasured hub mode Hj collapses into the teleported copy of A.\n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 The remaining mode Hj at the chosen leaf j now contains Alice\u2019s original unknown CV state (identity channel, zero added noise, because we post-select on zero outcomes).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the homodyne herald on M detectors, the two-mode correlation between input A and output Hj is the ideal identity mapping in the truncated CV Fock basis of interest.  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected teleportation gate (target_quantum correlating Fock amplitudes of A and Hj).\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of a \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d: by simply choosing which cluster nodes to measure (and which to leave unmeasured), one steers a CV teleportation link among many ports.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to tree or ring clusters for multi-path routing, load balancing, or broadcasting.  \n  \u2013 Enables systematic exploration of measurement-based CV network control, teleportation fidelities vs. cluster topology, and the interplay of post-selection probability vs. teleportation quality.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static homodyne detection as heralds\u2014no feedback loops, non-Gaussian ancillas, or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, homodyne bases, post-selection windows) for automated optimization and a whole family of novel multi-node CV network experiments.\n\nThis target focuses on a genuinely new network operation\u2014measurement-based routing of CV teleportation via Gaussian entanglement\u2014rather than merely generating a state or repeating known CV protocols, and is tailor-made for Pytheus exploration.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal reduces to CV cluster\u2010state teleportation/routing via homodyne post\u2010selection\u2014a well-studied method in the CV MBQC community. To reach PRL novelty you need a truly new ingredient (e.g. non-Gaussian cluster nodes, a novel joint measurement, or a routing capability that cannot be realized by standard CV one-way protocols).\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Description:\n  \u201cHeralded Non\u2010Gaussian Continuous-Variable Entanglement Swapping Network\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a novel entanglement-swapping protocol in the continuous-variable (CV) regime that combines Gaussian two-mode squeezing with a single non-Gaussian measurement at the central repeater.  By mixing two independent EPR pairs and performing a hybrid Bell measurement (one homodyne + one photon-count click) on the middle modes, one heralds high\u2010fidelity CV entanglement between two distant modes A and B.  This network transformation (entanglement swapping) goes beyond pure Gaussian swapping by injecting a non-Gaussian \u201cphoton subtraction\u201d element, opening a family of improved repeater protocols that Pytheus can optimize.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2022 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair between modes R\u2081 and X\u2081.  \n     \u2022 S\u2082 emits an EPR pair between modes R\u2082 and X\u2082.  \n     \u2013 R\u2081 will later mix with R\u2082 at the repeater; X\u2081 and X\u2082 become the distant modes A and B.  \n  2) Central repeater interferometer:\n     \u2022 Mix R\u2081 and R\u2082 on a beam splitter BS.  \n  3) Hybrid Bell measurement (heralding):\n     \u2022 Port 1 of BS \u2192 homodyne detector (measures X quadrature).  \n     \u2022 Port 2 of BS \u2192 weakly tapped to a number-resolving detector; a single\u2010photon click heralds a photon subtraction on one CV branch.  \n     \u2022 We post-select on (homodyne outcome \u22480) AND (exactly one photon click).  \n  4) Output:\n     \u2022 Upon this joint herald, modes X\u2081 (Alice\u2019s distant half) and X\u2082 (Bob\u2019s distant half) share a CV entangled state whose squeezing\u2014and hence teleportation performance\u2014exceeds that of a purely Gaussian swap.  \n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the joint herald event, the two\u2010mode correlation between X\u2081 and X\u2082 is a near\u2010perfect Gaussian entangled state (ideal two-mode squeezed state in the truncated Fock subspace of interest).  Pytheus can encode this as a post-selected target Quantum \u2192 {\u201c00\u201d+\u201c11\u201d+\u2026 up to chosen cutoff}, with number-resolving and homodyne detectors as ancilla heralds.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n  \u2013 First proposal for a CV entanglement swap that uses a non-Gaussian measurement to boost entanglement: \u201cphoton-subtracted\u201d swapping.  \n  \u2013 Yields a family of hybrid repeater protocols: vary the number of subtractions, homodyne quadratures, or concatenate multiple hops.  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of non-Gaussian resource placement in Gaussian networks and its impact on channel fidelity.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities:  \n     \u2022 Probabilistic two-mode squeezers (abstract EPR sources)  \n     \u2022 Static beam splitters & phase shifters (to mix R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n     \u2022 One homodyne detector + one number-resolving detector as heralds  \n     \u2022 Post-selection only (no dynamic feed-forward or cavities)  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can optimize beam-splitter ratios, squeezing strengths, tap reflectivity, and herald thresholds to maximize final entanglement (swap fidelity) over Fock-basis truncations.  \n\nThis target focuses on a genuinely new network transformation\u2014non-Gaussian-enhanced CV entanglement swapping\u2014rather than static state generation, and launches a whole suite of hybrid repeater experiments ripe for Pytheus\u2019s automated design."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Cascaded CV entanglement swapping chain: two independent two-mode squeezed sources link four parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D so that A and D become EPR-entangled by successive Bell-homodyne measurements, exploring noise build-up.  \n  3. CV teleportation ring: three nodes in a loop share three two-mode squeezers arranged in a triangle; an unknown CV input at A is teleported A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A in one shot, probing phase\u2010space \u201cholonomy.\u201d  \nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles.  \n  1. Controlled CV teleportation with more than one controller has been theorized only sparsely; discrete multi-controller is known, but full CV version with Gaussian GHZ and homodyne Bell measurements in linear optics has not been demonstrated. Pytheus can encode the abstract mode network (ancilla modes + homodyne detectors) and target \u201cconditional identity channel\u201d as a heralded multi-mode correlation.  \n  2. CV entanglement swapping is textbook; chaining two swaps adds little novelty.  \n  3. The teleportation ring is exotic conceptually but requires phase-space holonomy which is not obvious to encode as a final state target in Pytheus.  \nStep 3: Pick the multi-controller CV teleportation (idea 1).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because controlled teleportation in the continuous-variable regime has so far only been studied for a single controller (a three-mode Gaussian GHZ). Generalizing to N controllers opens a family of protocols\u2014quantum access control, threshold teleportation, and multipartite steering monogamy in a CV network.  \nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we can define an abstract (N+2)-mode target correlation: when all controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes fall into a given window (heralded events), the remaining two modes (Alice\u2019s output and Bob\u2019s output) must share perfect displacement\u2010corrected identity mapping of the input CV state. When all N+1 outcomes satisfy pre-set thresholds, Bob\u2019s mode requires only a known phase-space displacement to recover Alice\u2019s input.  \n\nTarget condition (abstract):  \n  \u2013 Heralded event \u21d2 the correlation of Bob\u2019s output and Alice\u2019s input modes is an ideal identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacement by the classical values read out from the N+1 detectors.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 N=1 recovers standard single-controller CV teleportation (three-mode GHZ).  \n  \u2013 N>1 introduces threshold access control: only unanimous (or k-of-N) consent yields perfect teleportation.  \n  \u2013 Probes monogamy of steering in CV GHZ states: how many controllers can simultaneously steer the teleportation channel?  \n  \u2013 Yields a whole family of linear-optics designs (vary N, vary k-threshold) with two\u2010mode squeezers and homodyne heralding\u2014perfect for Pytheus to optimize.  \n\nThis network focuses on teleportation and Gaussian entanglement in a truly multi-node setting, avoids static state generation targets, and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (pair sources + linear optics + heralded detection, no feedback loops).\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially already known as continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation/quantum secret sharing using Gaussian GHZ resources. By post-selecting on all N controller homodyne outcomes (plus Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne), Alice\u2019s unknown mode is teleported to Bob.  \n  2) \u201cCV Entanglement Swapping Chain with Dual Repeaters\u201d: two independent two-mode squeezed links A\u2013R1 and R2\u2013B, plus a third link R1\u2013R2; R1 and R2 perform homodyne Bell-measurements in tandem, heralding an EPR link A\u2013B. One studies routed CV entanglement over two hops without active feed-forward.  \n  3) \u201cMultiplexed Dual-Mode CV Teleportation\u201d: simultaneously teleport two independent CV modes from Alice1,2 to Bob1,2 using only three two-mode squeezers (rather than four) by a clever linear-optics network and four homodyne detectors, post-selecting on a joint measurement window.  \n\nStep 2: Compare novelty & Pytheus feasibility.  \n  1) N-Controller CV teleportation is known for N=1 but has not been ported to post-selected, multi-controller scenarios. Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci, one two-mode squeezer Si emits a pair between Ci\u2032 and Di\u2032.  \n  2) Linear-optics block: A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 are mixed via beam splitters & phase shifters (to entangle all N+2 modes into a GHZ-like state).  \n  3) Measurements (heralding):  \n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne: A (input) + A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2081,P\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci: homodyne on Ci\u2032 (either X or P as in Gaussian GHZ verification).  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes falling within small pre-set windows around zero.  \n  4) Output: Bob\u2019s mode B carries a displaced copy of Alice\u2019s input. Because we post-select on zero outcomes, no active displacement is needed.  \n\nTarget transformation (abstract):  \n  Conditioned on the joint herald event of N+1 detectors, the two-mode correlation between inputs A and output B is the identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacements set to zero by selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:  \n  \u2013 For N=1 it reduces to standard three-mode CV controlled teleportation; for N>1 it opens a family of threshold protocols (k-of-N control).  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite CV steering monogamy: how many controllers can simultaneously influence teleportation fidelity?  \n  \u2013 Suggests \u201centanglement routing\u201d in Gaussian networks: by selecting different subsets of controllers, one reconfigures teleportation links on demand.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich class of linear-optics designs (vary N, k) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014purely network/measurement transformations with probabilistic pair sources and post-selection.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme replicates standard CV controlled\u2010teleportation/secret\u2010sharing using Gaussian GHZ states. This merges CV teleportation with Gaussian network\u2010coding ideas.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources (probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 produces an EPR pair between A\u2032 and R\u2081.\n   \u2013 S\u2082 produces an EPR pair between B\u2032 and R\u2082.\n   \u2013 S\u2083 produces an EPR pair between R\u2083 and R\u2084.\n     \u2022 R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, R\u2084 are all routed into a central beam\u2010splitter network.\n2) Linear\u2010optics \u201cbutterfly\u201d block at the repeater node:\n   \u2013 R\u2081 & R\u2082 mix on BS\u2081,\n   \u2013 R\u2083 & R\u2084 mix on BS\u2082,\n   \u2013 One output of each BS is homodyned in X quadrature, the other in P quadrature (four homodyne detectors total).\n3) Local Bell homodyne measurements:\n   \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes (X,P).  \n   \u2013 Bob mixes his input mode B with B\u2032 similarly and homodynes.\n4) Heralding & post\u2010selection:\n   \u2013 We collect six homodyne outcomes (Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090; Bob\u2019s X_b,P_b; repeater\u2019s X_r1,P_r1,X_r2,P_r2).\n   \u2013 We post\u2010select on all six outcomes lying within small windows around zero.\n5) Output:\n   \u2013 Receivers C and D hold the remaining halves of S\u2083\u2019s EPR outputs. Under the joint herald condition, mode C reproduces Alice\u2019s original mode and mode D reproduces Bob\u2019s, each up to vanishing displacements (set to zero by our selection).\n\nTarget transformation (abstract):\n   \u2013 Conditioned on the six-detector herald event, the joint channels A\u2192C and B\u2192D are both ideal identity maps (zero added noise). Pytheus encodes this as two independent fidelity\u20101 teleportation targets in the Fock\u2010basis subspace of interest.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n   \u2013 First demonstration of CV network coding for teleportation: two flows sharing one repeater.  \n   \u2013 Resource compression: uses 3 squeezers instead of 4 for two independent teleports.  \n   \u2013 Opens a family of \u201cm\u2010flow\u201d Gaussian network\u2010coded teleportation protocols, plus extensions to k-of-N threshold flows and entanglement\u2010routing strategies.  \n   \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: pair sources + beam splitters + homodyne heralding + post\u2010selection, no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n   \u2013 Immediately yields a rich set of optimizable designs for diverse network\u2010coding topologies in continuous variables.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This protocol is essentially a straightforward CV analog of existing network-coded teleportation ideas without introducing a new resource or measurement. The resource is a single (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implemented via N+1 two-mode squeezers and a small linear-optics network.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair (A\u2032, B\u2032) for the Alice\u2013Bob channel.  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci (i=1\u2026N), Si emits an EPR pair (Ci\u2032, Di\u2032).  \n  2) GHZ interferometer:\n     \u2013 Mix A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 on a mesh of beam splitters and phase shifters to create an (N+2)-mode GHZ resource.  \n  3) Heralding measurements:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes the two outputs (X\u2090,P\u2090).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci homodynes their mode Di\u2032 in the designated quadrature.  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes lying within small windows around zero.  \n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B is then an exact copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise), without any active displacement (since we choose the zero outcome window).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  Conditioned on the joint herald event (Alice\u2019s Bell + N controller homodyne clicks), the two-mode correlation between A and B is the ideal identity channel.  In Pytheus this is encoded as a post-selected mapping that reproduces the input Fock-basis amplitudes at the output.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 N=1 recovers the standard three-mode controlled CV teleportation.  \n  \u2013 N>1 yields a rich family of \u201ck-of-N\u201d CV threshold teleportation/quantum-access protocols.  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite steering monogamy in Gaussian optics.  \n  \u2013 Suggests on-demand entanglement routing: by selecting different subsets of controllers one can dynamically reconfigure teleportation links.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: abstract two-mode squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne detectors as heralding ancillas, and no feedback loops.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can optimize these networks for any N, for different homodyne quadrature choices, and for different heralding thresholds\u2014yielding a broad platform of multi-node CV teleportation experiments.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme duplicates existing CV controlled\u2010teleportation/quantum secret\u2010sharing protocols. It uses only two-mode squeezers, beam splitters, one number-resolving herald and two homodyne heralds, all of which Pytheus can optimize.\n  B) Cascading two swaps with interleaved non-Gaussian steps is complex and less clearly transformative.\n  C) Hybrid CV/discrete routing is neat but mixes encodings in a way Pytheus can\u2019t abstractly represent.\nStep 3: Select idea A.\nStep 4: Novelty:  \n  \u2013 First proposal to integrate measurement-induced non-Gaussian entanglement distillation (photon subtraction on two independent Gaussian EPR pairs) with a post-selected CV teleportation in a single static linear-optics network.  \n  \u2013 Opens a spectrum of \u201cone-shot distill\u2010and\u2010teleport\u201d experiments, balancing resource squeezing vs. detection events.  \nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n  \u2013 Uses only probabilistic two-mode squeezers, beam splitters & phase shifters, one number-resolving detector (ancilla mode for photon subtraction), two homodyne detectors (Alice\u2019s Bell measurement), all treated as heralding events\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n  \u2013 Target: a post-selected identity channel between Alice\u2019s input mode and Bob\u2019s output mode, conditioned on three herald clicks.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can optimize the beam-splitter reflectivities, phase settings, and heralding thresholds to maximize teleportation fidelity.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cMeasurement-Enhanced One-Shot CV Teleportation via Gaussian Entanglement Distillation\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a single static linear-optics network that both distills Gaussian entanglement by photon subtraction and immediately uses it to teleport an unknown continuous-variable (CV) input.  By merging the two steps, one saves resources, explores the interplay of non-Gaussian induction and teleportation fidelity, and opens a family of \u201cdistill-and-teleport\u201d protocols.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2081 creates an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032 (used for the teleportation channel).\n     \u2013 S\u2082 and S\u2083 each create an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for distillation).\n  2) Distillation block:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2032 and D\u2032 on a beam splitter (BS\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Place a number-resolving detector (ancilla herald) on one output port; a single-photon click heralds that the joint C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 modes have undergone photon subtraction, increasing their entanglement with A\u2032\u2013B\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation block:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS, then homodynes both outputs (X\u2090 and P\u2090 detectors).\n     \u2013 We post-select on the single-photon click plus X\u2090\u22480 and P\u2090\u22480 (small windows around zero).\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B\u2032 holds the teleported copy of A, conditioned on the three herald events.  No active displacement is needed because we choose zero-outcome post-selection.\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on one single-photon detection and two homodyne outcomes \u22480, the joint mapping A\u2192B\u2032 is the identity channel (zero added noise within the truncated Fock subspace).  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected correlation of Fock-basis amplitudes between A and B\u2032.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n  \u2013 Introduces the first integrated \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d network: distillation and teleportation are not separate modules but a single optimized layout.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can explore a wide parameter space: balance of squeezing levels in S\u2081\u2013S\u2083, beam-splitter ratios at BS\u2081, heralding thresholds, and detector placements to maximize fidelity.  \n  \u2013 Yields a family of experiments: vary the number of photon-subtraction ancillas, swap different quadratures, or extend to multiple input modes.  \n  \u2013 Fully compatible with Pytheus: only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static number-resolving and homodyne heralding; no dynamic feedback, cavities, or hyper-entanglement.  \n\nThis network opens a new domain of entanglement-distillation-augmented teleportation transformations in Gaussian optics, offering both theoretical depth (non-Gaussian induction + CV channel capacity) and practical breadth (tunable experimental designs).\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d protocol duplicates well-established CV schemes that use photon subtraction to improve teleportation fidelity. The resource is a simple star-shaped CV cluster state (Gaussian entanglement), generated by two-mode squeezers and beam splitters. No active displacements or feed-forward control is required: we post-select on homodyne outcomes near zero to effect perfect teleportation along the selected branch.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 For each of M leaves (ports) we have one two-mode squeezer that emits an EPR pair between leaf mode Li\u2032 and its corresponding cluster hub mode Hi.  \n     \u2013 The M hub modes H1\u2026HM are then mixed pairwise on a small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to create the star-cluster entanglement across all M+1 modes (the +1 is the central cluster node where all Hi meet).\n  2) Input coupling:\n     \u2013 An unknown CV mode A (sitting at leaf Lk) is coupled by a 50:50 beam splitter to its ancilla squeezed half Lk\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation measurements:\n     \u2013 We homodyne both outputs of that 50:50 BS in X and P quadratures\u2014call these detectors BX,BP.  \n     \u2013 We then homodyne all hub modes Hi except the one leading to the desired output leaf Lj in a fixed quadrature (e.g. X). By selecting which Hi not to measure, we choose the output port.  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 We accept only events where all homodyne outcomes (BX\u22480, BP\u22480, and the M\u20131 hub homodyne results \u22480) lie within small preset windows.  \n     \u2013 Under this collective herald, the unmeasured hub mode Hj collapses into the teleported copy of A.\n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 The remaining mode Hj at the chosen leaf j now contains Alice\u2019s original unknown CV state (identity channel, zero added noise, because we post-select on zero outcomes).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the homodyne herald on M detectors, the two-mode correlation between input A and output Hj is the ideal identity mapping in the truncated CV Fock basis of interest.  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected teleportation gate (target_quantum correlating Fock amplitudes of A and Hj).\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of a \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d: by simply choosing which cluster nodes to measure (and which to leave unmeasured), one steers a CV teleportation link among many ports.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to tree or ring clusters for multi-path routing, load balancing, or broadcasting.  \n  \u2013 Enables systematic exploration of measurement-based CV network control, teleportation fidelities vs. cluster topology, and the interplay of post-selection probability vs. teleportation quality.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static homodyne detection as heralds\u2014no feedback loops, non-Gaussian ancillas, or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, homodyne bases, post-selection windows) for automated optimization and a whole family of novel multi-node CV network experiments.\n\nThis target focuses on a genuinely new network operation\u2014measurement-based routing of CV teleportation via Gaussian entanglement\u2014rather than merely generating a state or repeating known CV protocols, and is tailor-made for Pytheus exploration.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal reduces to CV cluster\u2010state teleportation/routing via homodyne post\u2010selection\u2014a well-studied method in the CV MBQC community.     "output": "Here is a proposal for a truly new CV-Gaussian quantum network transformation\u2014no static state-generation, only teleportation & entanglement in a multi-node topology.\n\nDescription:\n\u201cCyclic Continuous-Variable Teleportation Network\u201d  \nA network of N unknown CV modes arranged on a ring is wired so that each mode is teleported one step around the cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, \u2026, (Nth)\u2192A\u2014in one static linear-optics layout with only Gaussian entanglement (EPR pairs) and homodyne post-selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s new:\n1) It implements an N-party cyclic permutation channel entirely via CV teleportation, rather than independent point-to-point links.  \n2) It probes how teleportation noise and entanglement swap around a closed loop, a question not studied before.  \n3) It yields a family of experiments (vary N) and explores the interplay of network topology, squeezing resources, and post-selection thresholds.  \n\nGeneral network sketch (for N=4, generalizable to any N):  \n1) EPR sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):  \n   \u2022 S\u2081 \u2194 modes A\u2032\u2013B\u2032  \n   \u2022 S\u2082 \u2194 modes B\u2033\u2013C\u2032  \n   \u2022 S\u2083 \u2194 modes C\u2033\u2013D\u2032  \n   \u2022 S\u2084 \u2194 modes D\u2033\u2013A\u2033  \n\n2) Bell-measurement modules (one per input mode):  \n   For each original input mode X\u2208{A,B,C,D}:  \n     \u2013 Mix X with its corresponding EPR half (e.g. A with A\u2032) on a 50:50 BS.  \n     \u2013 Homodyne both BS outputs in X and P quadratures \u2192 two detectors per input.  \n\n3) Remaining modes after all four Bell modules are B\u2032, C\u2032, D\u2032, A\u2033.  Under perfect teleportation, these hold A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192D, D\u2192A.  \n\n4) Heralding & post-selection:  \n   \u2013 Collect 8 homodyne outcomes (2 per input Bell measurement).  \n   \u2013 Post-select on all outcomes \u2248 0 (small pre-set windows).  Because zero quadrature results correspond to zero displacement, no feed-forward is needed.  \n\n5) Output:  \n   \u2013 Mode B\u2032 contains A\u2019s input state; C\u2032 contains B\u2019s; D\u2032 contains C\u2019s; A\u2033 contains D\u2019s.  \n   \u2013 Thus the network enacts the cyclic permutation channel (A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D\u2192A) with ideal fidelity (zero added noise in the post-selected subspace).  \n\nAbstract target:\n   A heralded N-mode mapping that, conditioned on 2N zero-outcome homodyne clicks, realizes the unitary permutation of the N input CV modes onto the N output modes with no extra noise.  \n\nExtensions & research directions:  \n \u2022 Vary N to study scaling of teleportation noise around loops.  \n \u2022 Trade off squeezing strength vs. post-selection probability.  \n \u2022 Probe how partial post-selection (e.g. only 2N\u2013k zeros) yields mixed-order permutations or interference effects.  \n \u2022 Compare ring vs. line vs. more complex graph topologies (e.g. M\u00f6bius rings!) for CV channel routing.  \n\nSuitability for Pytheus:  \n \u2022 Only uses probabilistic two-mode squeezers (abstract EPR sources), beam splitters & phase shifters (linear optics), and homodyne detectors as heralding ancillas.  \n \u2022 No cavities, non-Gaussian ancillas, dynamic feed-forward or hyper-entanglement needed.  \n \u2022 The Expert can encode the target \u201ccyclic permutation channel\u201d by feeding in maximally entangled test states and demanding the corresponding Choi-state correlations, or by specifying the post-selected identity mapping on a truncated Fock basis across input/output pairs.  \n \u2022 A whole family of networks (varying N, squeezing levels, BS ratios, herald thresholds) awaits automated optimization by Pytheus.  \n\nThis cyclic-teleportation network combines continuous-variable teleportation with Gaussian entanglement in a genuinely multi-node transformation\u2014opening a new domain of looped quantum channels and their fundamental noise and correlation properties."
}

Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"cv teleportation\" and \"gaussian entanglement\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. N-party controlled CV teleportation: use an (N+1)-mode Gaussian GHZ state to teleport a qumode from Alice to Bob only if all N controllers cooperatively measure their modes.  \n  2. Cascaded CV entanglement swapping chain: two independent two-mode squeezed sources link four parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D so that A and D become EPR-entangled by successive Bell-homodyne measurements, exploring noise build-up.  \n  3. CV teleportation ring: three nodes in a loop share three two-mode squeezers arranged in a triangle; an unknown CV input at A is teleported A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A in one shot, probing phase\u2010space \u201cholonomy.\u201d  \nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles.  \n  1. Controlled CV teleportation with more than one controller has been theorized only sparsely; discrete multi-controller is known, but full CV version with Gaussian GHZ and homodyne Bell measurements in linear optics has not been demonstrated. Pytheus can encode the abstract mode network (ancilla modes + homodyne detectors) and target \u201cconditional identity channel\u201d as a heralded multi-mode correlation.  \n  2. CV entanglement swapping is textbook; chaining two swaps adds little novelty.  \n  3. The teleportation ring is exotic conceptually but requires phase-space holonomy which is not obvious to encode as a final state target in Pytheus.  \nStep 3: Pick the multi-controller CV teleportation (idea 1).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because controlled teleportation in the continuous-variable regime has so far only been studied for a single controller (a three-mode Gaussian GHZ). Generalizing to N controllers opens a family of protocols\u2014quantum access control, threshold teleportation, and multipartite steering monogamy in a CV network.  \nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we can define an abstract (N+2)-mode target correlation: when all controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes fall into a given window (heralded events), the remaining two modes (Alice\u2019s output and Bob\u2019s output) must share perfect displacement\u2010corrected identity mapping of the input CV state. Pytheus can search for a linear\u2010optics network of two-mode squeezers (abstract ancilla pair sources), beam splitters, homodyne detectors (heralding), and classical feed-forward labels (heralded outputs), without requiring dynamic feedback or cavities.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription: \u201cMulti-Controller Continuous-Variable Teleportation Network\u201d  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a generalized CV controlled-teleportation protocol in which an unknown optical mode (Alice\u2019s input) is teleported to Bob only when N independent controllers (C1, C2, \u2026, CN) jointly perform designated homodyne measurements on their share of an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ resource.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flowing top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources: N+2 two-mode squeezed ancilla pair sources.  \n    \u2013 Each source emits a pair: one half goes to one of the N controllers, the other half connects into a central beam-splitter network.  \n    \u2013 Two additional squeezers provide the Alice\u2013Bob entangled channel.  \n  \u2022 Linear optics block: a multiport interferometer that mixes all controller modes and Bob\u2019s share with ancilla modes, adjustable via beam splitters and phase shifters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n    \u2013 N homodyne detectors (one per controller) on their output arms, performing X or P measurements as in standard CV GHZ verification.  \n    \u2013 Two additional homodyne detectors performing the Bell-measurement for Alice\u2019s input and her half of the CV entangled pair.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: we post-select on a joint measurement event window across all N+1 detectors (Alice\u2019s Bell measurement plus controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes). When all N+1 outcomes satisfy pre-set thresholds, Bob\u2019s mode requires only a known phase-space displacement to recover Alice\u2019s input.  \n\nTarget condition (abstract):  \n  \u2013 Heralded event \u21d2 the correlation of Bob\u2019s output and Alice\u2019s input modes is an ideal identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacement by the classical values read out from the N+1 detectors.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 N=1 recovers standard single-controller CV teleportation (three-mode GHZ).  \n  \u2013 N>1 introduces threshold access control: only unanimous (or k-of-N) consent yields perfect teleportation.  \n  \u2013 Probes monogamy of steering in CV GHZ states: how many controllers can simultaneously steer the teleportation channel?  \n  \u2013 Yields a whole family of linear-optics designs (vary N, vary k-threshold) with two\u2010mode squeezers and homodyne heralding\u2014perfect for Pytheus to optimize.  \n\nThis network focuses on teleportation and Gaussian entanglement in a truly multi-node setting, avoids static state generation targets, and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (pair sources + linear optics + heralded detection, no feedback loops).\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially already known as continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation/quantum secret sharing using Gaussian GHZ resources. By post-selecting on all N controller homodyne outcomes (plus Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne), Alice\u2019s unknown mode is teleported to Bob.  \n  2) \u201cCV Entanglement Swapping Chain with Dual Repeaters\u201d: two independent two-mode squeezed links A\u2013R1 and R2\u2013B, plus a third link R1\u2013R2; R1 and R2 perform homodyne Bell-measurements in tandem, heralding an EPR link A\u2013B. One studies routed CV entanglement over two hops without active feed-forward.  \n  3) \u201cMultiplexed Dual-Mode CV Teleportation\u201d: simultaneously teleport two independent CV modes from Alice1,2 to Bob1,2 using only three two-mode squeezers (rather than four) by a clever linear-optics network and four homodyne detectors, post-selecting on a joint measurement window.  \n\nStep 2: Compare novelty & Pytheus feasibility.  \n  1) N-Controller CV teleportation is known for N=1 but has not been ported to post-selected, multi-controller scenarios. It directly targets a teleportation transformation (identity channel) and uses only squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne detectors, and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n  2) Chaining two CV swaps is incremental, lacks fresh physics.  \n  3) Multiplexed teleportation with resource compression is interesting but more intricate to encode and its physics novelty is marginal compared to the controlled-teleportation network.  \n\nStep 3: Choose idea (1).  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because controlled continuous-variable teleportation beyond a single controller (N>1) has not been realized in a post-selected linear-optics setting. It yields a whole family of \u201ck-of-N\u201d threshold teleportation protocols, new tests of CV steering monogamy, and network-routing concepts in Gaussian optics.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because we only require:  \n  \u2022 Abstract two-mode squeezed sources (probabilistic pair sources).  \n  \u2022 A fixed interferometer of beam splitters & phase shifters mixing N controller arms + Alice\u2019s Bell port + Bob\u2019s GHZ port.  \n  \u2022 Homodyne detectors treated as heralding \u201cancilla detectors\u201d with post-selection windows (no dynamic feedback).  \n  \u2022 A target transformation: conditioned on N+1 herald clicks (Alice\u2019s Bell + N controllers within thresholds), Bob\u2019s output mode reproduces Alice\u2019s input (identity mapping).  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription: \u201cPost-Selected Multi-Controller CV Teleportation via Gaussian GHZ\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe consider a network of (N+2) optical modes:  \n  \u2022 Alice\u2019s input mode (mode A) carries an unknown CV state.  \n  \u2022 Bob\u2019s output mode (mode B) will receive the teleported state.  \n  \u2022 N controller modes (C\u2081\u2026C\u2099).  \n\nResource: one (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implementable via N+1 two-mode squeezed ancilla sources interlinked by a small linear-optics circuit.  \n\nNetwork layout (modes flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  1) Probabilistic sources:  \n     \u2013 Two-mode squeezers S\u2080 emit EPR pairs between A\u2032 and B\u2032 (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci, one two-mode squeezer Si emits a pair between Ci\u2032 and Di\u2032.  \n  2) Linear-optics block: A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 are mixed via beam splitters & phase shifters (to entangle all N+2 modes into a GHZ-like state).  \n  3) Measurements (heralding):  \n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne: A (input) + A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2081,P\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci: homodyne on Ci\u2032 (either X or P as in Gaussian GHZ verification).  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes falling within small pre-set windows around zero.  \n  4) Output: Bob\u2019s mode B carries a displaced copy of Alice\u2019s input. Because we post-select on zero outcomes, no active displacement is needed.  \n\nTarget transformation (abstract):  \n  Conditioned on the joint herald event of N+1 detectors, the two-mode correlation between inputs A and output B is the identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacements set to zero by selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:  \n  \u2013 For N=1 it reduces to standard three-mode CV controlled teleportation; for N>1 it opens a family of threshold protocols (k-of-N control).  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite CV steering monogamy: how many controllers can simultaneously influence teleportation fidelity?  \n  \u2013 Suggests \u201centanglement routing\u201d in Gaussian networks: by selecting different subsets of controllers, one reconfigures teleportation links on demand.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich class of linear-optics designs (vary N, k) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014purely network/measurement transformations with probabilistic pair sources and post-selection.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme replicates standard CV controlled\u2010teleportation/secret\u2010sharing using Gaussian GHZ states. For a truly novel PRL\u2010level target you must introduce a new non-Gaussian element, a novel measurement strategy, or a network capability beyond existing Gaussian steering/teleportation frameworks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Uses only pair sources, beam splitters, homodyne detectors, heralding\u2014fits Pytheus.  \n  B) Straight CV chain is incremental.  \n  C) CV network coding is a fresh analog of the discrete butterfly network; genuinely new multi\u2010flow teleportation using Gaussian entanglement with resource compression. Also purely linear\u2010optics + homodyne + heralding.  \nStep 3: Pick the CV butterfly network coding idea (C).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it port s the concept of \u201cnetwork coding\u201d into the continuous\u2010variable teleportation world, showing two simultaneous CV teleportation flows sharing a common repeater node and resource, reducing the number of two\u2010mode squeezers needed and probing interference of Gaussian channels in a genuinely network\u2010coded way.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we only require:  \n  \u2022 Abstract two\u2010mode squeezed pair sources (probabilistic).  \n  \u2022 A small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) at the central node.  \n  \u2022 Homodyne detectors as heralds (no dynamic feed\u2010forward).  \n  \u2022 A post-selection condition on homodyne outcomes that ensures at the two output receivers the identity mapping for each input CV mode.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription: \u201cCV Butterfly Network\u2010Coding Teleportation\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe propose a four\u2010node CV teleportation network in the classic \u201cbutterfly\u201d topology, enabling two unknown optical modes (from senders A and B) to be simultaneously teleported to two receivers (C and D) through a single intermediate repeater, employing Gaussian entanglement and homodyne heralding. This merges CV teleportation with Gaussian network\u2010coding ideas.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources (probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 produces an EPR pair between A\u2032 and R\u2081.\n   \u2013 S\u2082 produces an EPR pair between B\u2032 and R\u2082.\n   \u2013 S\u2083 produces an EPR pair between R\u2083 and R\u2084.\n     \u2022 R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, R\u2084 are all routed into a central beam\u2010splitter network.\n2) Linear\u2010optics \u201cbutterfly\u201d block at the repeater node:\n   \u2013 R\u2081 & R\u2082 mix on BS\u2081,\n   \u2013 R\u2083 & R\u2084 mix on BS\u2082,\n   \u2013 One output of each BS is homodyned in X quadrature, the other in P quadrature (four homodyne detectors total).\n3) Local Bell homodyne measurements:\n   \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes (X,P).  \n   \u2013 Bob mixes his input mode B with B\u2032 similarly and homodynes.\n4) Heralding & post\u2010selection:\n   \u2013 We collect six homodyne outcomes (Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090; Bob\u2019s X_b,P_b; repeater\u2019s X_r1,P_r1,X_r2,P_r2).\n   \u2013 We post\u2010select on all six outcomes lying within small windows around zero.\n5) Output:\n   \u2013 Receivers C and D hold the remaining halves of S\u2083\u2019s EPR outputs. Under the joint herald condition, mode C reproduces Alice\u2019s original mode and mode D reproduces Bob\u2019s, each up to vanishing displacements (set to zero by our selection).\n\nTarget transformation (abstract):\n   \u2013 Conditioned on the six-detector herald event, the joint channels A\u2192C and B\u2192D are both ideal identity maps (zero added noise). Pytheus encodes this as two independent fidelity\u20101 teleportation targets in the Fock\u2010basis subspace of interest.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n   \u2013 First demonstration of CV network coding for teleportation: two flows sharing one repeater.  \n   \u2013 Resource compression: uses 3 squeezers instead of 4 for two independent teleports.  \n   \u2013 Opens a family of \u201cm\u2010flow\u201d Gaussian network\u2010coded teleportation protocols, plus extensions to k-of-N threshold flows and entanglement\u2010routing strategies.  \n   \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: pair sources + beam splitters + homodyne heralding + post\u2010selection, no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n   \u2013 Immediately yields a rich set of optimizable designs for diverse network\u2010coding topologies in continuous variables.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This protocol is essentially a straightforward CV analog of existing network-coded teleportation ideas without introducing a new resource or measurement. The resource is a single (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implemented via N+1 two-mode squeezers and a small linear-optics network.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair (A\u2032, B\u2032) for the Alice\u2013Bob channel.  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci (i=1\u2026N), Si emits an EPR pair (Ci\u2032, Di\u2032).  \n  2) GHZ interferometer:\n     \u2013 Mix A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 on a mesh of beam splitters and phase shifters to create an (N+2)-mode GHZ resource.  \n  3) Heralding measurements:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes the two outputs (X\u2090,P\u2090).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci homodynes their mode Di\u2032 in the designated quadrature.  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes lying within small windows around zero.  \n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B is then an exact copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise), without any active displacement (since we choose the zero outcome window).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  Conditioned on the joint herald event (Alice\u2019s Bell + N controller homodyne clicks), the two-mode correlation between A and B is the ideal identity channel.  In Pytheus this is encoded as a post-selected mapping that reproduces the input Fock-basis amplitudes at the output.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 N=1 recovers the standard three-mode controlled CV teleportation.  \n  \u2013 N>1 yields a rich family of \u201ck-of-N\u201d CV threshold teleportation/quantum-access protocols.  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite steering monogamy in Gaussian optics.  \n  \u2013 Suggests on-demand entanglement routing: by selecting different subsets of controllers one can dynamically reconfigure teleportation links.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: abstract two-mode squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne detectors as heralding ancillas, and no feedback loops.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can optimize these networks for any N, for different homodyne quadrature choices, and for different heralding thresholds\u2014yielding a broad platform of multi-node CV teleportation experiments.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme duplicates existing CV controlled\u2010teleportation/quantum secret\u2010sharing protocols. By merging the two steps, one saves resources, explores the interplay of non-Gaussian induction and teleportation fidelity, and opens a family of \u201cdistill-and-teleport\u201d protocols.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2081 creates an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032 (used for the teleportation channel).\n     \u2013 S\u2082 and S\u2083 each create an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for distillation).\n  2) Distillation block:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2032 and D\u2032 on a beam splitter (BS\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Place a number-resolving detector (ancilla herald) on one output port; a single-photon click heralds that the joint C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 modes have undergone photon subtraction, increasing their entanglement with A\u2032\u2013B\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation block:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS, then homodynes both outputs (X\u2090 and P\u2090 detectors).\n     \u2013 We post-select on the single-photon click plus X\u2090\u22480 and P\u2090\u22480 (small windows around zero).\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B\u2032 holds the teleported copy of A, conditioned on the three herald events.  No active displacement is needed because we choose zero-outcome post-selection.\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on one single-photon detection and two homodyne outcomes \u22480, the joint mapping A\u2192B\u2032 is the identity channel (zero added noise within the truncated Fock subspace). By combining Gaussian entanglement with a non-Gaussian control measurement, this hybrid threshold protocol opens a new class of CV quantum-access networks.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):  \n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair between modes C\u2032 and D (controller channel).  \n  2) Teleportation Bell measurement at Alice:  \n     \u2013 Mix A and A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne both outputs in X and P quadratures \u2192 detectors H\u2081,H\u2082.  \n  3) Gaussian controller (Charlie\u2081):  \n     \u2013 Homodyne mode C\u2032 in a designated quadrature \u2192 detector H\u2083.  \n  4) Discrete controller (Charlie\u2082):  \n     \u2013 Tap mode D via a weak beam splitter \u2192 number-resolving detector P\u2081; a single-photon click flags approval.  \n  5) Post-selection (no active feed-forward):  \n     \u2013 We accept only events where H\u2081\u22480, H\u2082\u22480 and H\u2083\u22480 (all within small windows) and exactly one photon in P\u2081.  \n  6) Output:  \n     \u2013 Under this joint herald, Bob\u2019s mode B is an ideal copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise, no displacement needed).\n\nAbstract target transformation:  \n  \u2013 Conditioned on the four herald clicks (three homodynes within zero thresholds plus one photon-count click), the Fock-basis amplitudes at A and B are perfectly correlated (ideal teleportation).  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected mapping that reproduces Alice\u2019s input at Bob.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 First hybrid CV/discrete threshold teleportation network\u2014blends Gaussian entanglement with a non-Gaussian control.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of (k\u2081 homodyne + k\u2082 photon) threshold protocols: how many Gaussian/non-Gaussian controllers are needed to secure the channel?  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of hybrid steering and non-Gaussian resource placement in a multi-node network.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: two-mode squeezers, static linear optics, homodyne and number-resolving detectors, post-selection only.  \n  \u2013 A rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, herald thresholds) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014spawning diverse experiments under one conceptual roof.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal merely grafts a single-photon click onto standard Gaussian CV controlled teleportation. To reach PRL novelty you must add a genuinely new non\u2010Gaussian resource or joint measurement capability (beyond a trivial photon\u2010count tap) that yields qualitatively new steering or channel features.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to weave \u201ccv teleportation\u201d with \u201cgaussian entanglement\u201d into a pure network/measurement transformation (no forbidden state-generation targets):\n  1) Post-selected multi-controller CV teleportation via (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ (all homodyne controllers) \u2013 we\u2019ve already tried this: too close to known CV secret-sharing.\n  2) CV \u201cbutterfly\u201d network-coded teleportation \u2013 two flows through one repeater; marginal novelty.\n  3) Measurement-based CV teleportation router on a star-cluster: use a small Gaussian cluster state as a passive switch to teleport an unknown CV input from one leaf to any chosen output leaf, purely by selecting which intermediate modes to homodyne, all in a single static linear-optics network with post-selection on zero outcomes.\nStep 2: Check novelty & obstacles:\n  1) Known. Pytheus can do it but not novel.\n  2) Close to independent teleporters \u2013 novelty low.\n  3) Cluster-based teleportation routing has not been demonstrated in CV experiments without active feed-forward. It genuinely combines Gaussian entanglement (cluster resource) and CV teleportation in a network-routing context. Pytheus can optimize a network of squeezers, beam splitters, and homodyne detectors with post-selection\u2014no feedback loops or cavities needed.\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\nStep 4: Novelty:  \n  \u2013 Introduces the first \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d network that uses a small Gaussian cluster state as a switch: by choosing which intermediate cluster node(s) to homodyne and post-selecting on zero outcomes, one routes an unknown CV mode from any input leaf to any desired output leaf.  \n  \u2013 Opens a broad family of CV entanglement-routing protocols: star, tree, ring, where measurement patterns alone steer the teleportation path.  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of measurement-based CV network control in a static linear-optics layout.\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n  \u2013 Only uses abstract two-mode squeezers (probabilistic pair sources), a static interferometer of beam splitters & phase shifters to build the cluster, and homodyne detectors as heralds (ancilla detectors) with post-selection windows.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement \u2014 all within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cPassive CV Teleportation Router via a Gaussian Star-Cluster State\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a small measurement-based continuous-variable (CV) teleportation network that acts as a passive \u201crouter,\u201d directing an unknown input mode from any chosen input port (leaf) to any selected output port (leaf) solely by the choice of homodyne measurements on intermediate cluster nodes. The resource is a simple star-shaped CV cluster state (Gaussian entanglement), generated by two-mode squeezers and beam splitters. No active displacements or feed-forward control is required: we post-select on homodyne outcomes near zero to effect perfect teleportation along the selected branch.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 For each of M leaves (ports) we have one two-mode squeezer that emits an EPR pair between leaf mode Li\u2032 and its corresponding cluster hub mode Hi.  \n     \u2013 The M hub modes H1\u2026HM are then mixed pairwise on a small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to create the star-cluster entanglement across all M+1 modes (the +1 is the central cluster node where all Hi meet).\n  2) Input coupling:\n     \u2013 An unknown CV mode A (sitting at leaf Lk) is coupled by a 50:50 beam splitter to its ancilla squeezed half Lk\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation measurements:\n     \u2013 We homodyne both outputs of that 50:50 BS in X and P quadratures\u2014call these detectors BX,BP.  \n     \u2013 We then homodyne all hub modes Hi except the one leading to the desired output leaf Lj in a fixed quadrature (e.g. X). By selecting which Hi not to measure, we choose the output port.  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 We accept only events where all homodyne outcomes (BX\u22480, BP\u22480, and the M\u20131 hub homodyne results \u22480) lie within small preset windows.  \n     \u2013 Under this collective herald, the unmeasured hub mode Hj collapses into the teleported copy of A.\n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 The remaining mode Hj at the chosen leaf j now contains Alice\u2019s original unknown CV state (identity channel, zero added noise, because we post-select on zero outcomes).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the homodyne herald on M detectors, the two-mode correlation between input A and output Hj is the ideal identity mapping in the truncated CV Fock basis of interest.  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected teleportation gate (target_quantum correlating Fock amplitudes of A and Hj).\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of a \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d: by simply choosing which cluster nodes to measure (and which to leave unmeasured), one steers a CV teleportation link among many ports.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to tree or ring clusters for multi-path routing, load balancing, or broadcasting.  \n  \u2013 Enables systematic exploration of measurement-based CV network control, teleportation fidelities vs. cluster topology, and the interplay of post-selection probability vs. teleportation quality.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static homodyne detection as heralds\u2014no feedback loops, non-Gaussian ancillas, or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, homodyne bases, post-selection windows) for automated optimization and a whole family of novel multi-node CV network experiments.\n\nThis target focuses on a genuinely new network operation\u2014measurement-based routing of CV teleportation via Gaussian entanglement\u2014rather than merely generating a state or repeating known CV protocols, and is tailor-made for Pytheus exploration.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal reduces to CV cluster\u2010state teleportation/routing via homodyne post\u2010selection\u2014a well-studied method in the CV MBQC community. To reach PRL novelty you need a truly new ingredient (e.g. non-Gaussian cluster nodes, a novel joint measurement, or a routing capability that cannot be realized by standard CV one-way protocols).\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three purely network\u2010based ways to marry CV teleportation with Gaussian entanglement (no forbidden state\u2010generation targets):\n  1) Post\u2010selected N-controller CV teleportation via an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ  \n  2) CV network\u2010coded \u201cbutterfly\u201d teleportation: two flows through one repeater  \n  3) Multi-path CV teleportation with interference-enhanced fidelity  \nStep 2: Assess novelty & feasibility:\n  1) Already well-studied as CV secret-sharing.  \n  2) Marginally new\u2014essentially two independent teleporters sharing a repeater.  \n  3) Novel: by teleporting over two parallel Gaussian EPR chains and recombining at the receiver via interference and post-selection, one can outperform single-path fidelity. Uses only two-mode squeezers, beam splitters and homodyne heralds\u2014Pytheus-compatible.  \nStep 3: Choose idea 3.  \nStep 4: Novelty:  \n  \u2013 Introduces \u201cmulti\u2010path CV teleportation\u201d: two (or more) independent entanglement-swapping chains whose outputs interfere at the receiver to suppress noise. Explores network\u2010coded error resilience in Gaussian optics.  \nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n  \u2013 Abstract two-mode squeezed pair sources for each link, static beam-splitter network for the two swap stations and the final interference BS, homodyne heralding at each swap and at one output port, post-selection on zero outcomes. No dynamic feedback or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cMulti-Path Continuous-Variable Teleportation via Gaussian Entanglement Interference\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown CV mode from Alice (A) to Bob (B) by routing it simultaneously over two parallel Gaussian entanglement channels and then recombining them at the receiver via interference and post-selection. By post-selecting on zero outcomes from three Bell-homodyne swap stations (two at the intermediate nodes, one at the final combiner), Bob\u2019s output mode realizes an identity channel with fidelity exceeding that of any single path. This architecture opens a new paradigm of CV network coding and error-suppressed teleportation across multiple hops without active feed-forward.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) EPR sources:\n     \u2013 S\u2081: two-mode squeezer between ancilla A\u2081 and swap station X  \n     \u2013 S\u2082: two-mode squeezer between ancilla A\u2082 and swap station Y  \n     \u2013 S\u2083: two-mode squeezer between X\u2032 and combiner input C\u2081  \n     \u2013 S\u2084: two-mode squeezer between Y\u2032 and combiner input C\u2082  \n  2) Swap stations:\n     \u2013 At X: mix A\u2081 & X on a 50:50 BS, homodyne both outputs (two herald detectors H\u2081,H\u2082).  \n     \u2013 At Y: same procedure \u2192 heralds H\u2083,H\u2084.  \n  3) Combiner:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2081 & C\u2082 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne one output port (herald H\u2085), leave the other port as Bob\u2019s mode.  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 Accept only events where H\u2081\u2026H\u2085 all \u22480 (small windows).  \n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s mode is the teleported copy of A (ideal identity channel in the post-selected subspace).\n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of multi-path CV teleportation with interference-based noise suppression.  \n  \u2013 Extensible to N-path teleportation or 2D lattice percolation of CV entanglement.  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of network coding, entanglement percolation, and error resilience in Gaussian optics.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: probabilistic two-mode squeezers, static beam splitters/phase-shifters, homodyne heralding (ancilla detectors), and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feedback or cavity physics."
