    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible CV teleportation\u2013Gaussian entanglement networks (no state\u2010gen targets, only teleportation/swapping transformations):\n  1) N\u2010controller post\u2010selected CV teleportation via an (N+2)\u2010mode Gaussian GHZ (all homodyne controllers).  \n  2) CV \u201cbutterfly\u201d network\u2013coded teleportation: two simultaneous CV flows sharing one repeater.  \n  3) Heralded CV teleportation with embedded Noiseless Linear Amplifier (NLA): integrate photon\u2010catalysis\u2013based NLA modules into a single linear\u2010optics network that both distills and teleports in one shot.\nStep 2: Compare novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n  1) Well known as CV secret\u2010sharing.  \n  2) Essentially two independent teleporters\u2014low novelty.  \n  3) Genuinely new network\u2010transformation: a single static layout of pair\u2010sources, beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving heralds that implements both non\u2010Gaussian entanglement distillation (via photon catalysis) and a CV teleportation channel. Pytheus supports pair sources, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection, with no active feed-forward or cavities.\nStep 3: Pick idea (3): \u201cNLA-augmented CV Teleportation.\u201d\nStep 4: Novelty: This is the first proposal for a one\u2010shot network that merges heralded Gaussian entanglement distillation (photon\u2010catalysis NLA) with CV teleportation in a single static interferometer, opening a broad class of \u201cdistill-and-teleport\u201d transformations in Gaussian optics.\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n  \u2022 Uses only abstract two-mode squeezers (probabilistic pair sources), beam splitters & phase shifters, one number-resolving ancilla detector for photon catalysis, two number-resolving detectors for the Bell\u2010swap herald, and post-selection.  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback or cavities\u2014Pytheus can optimize all reflectivities, phases, and heralding placements to realize a heralded identity channel (in a truncated Fock subspace) between Alice\u2019s input and Bob\u2019s output.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cOne-Shot Noiseless-Linear-Amplified Continuous-Variable Teleportation via Photon-Catalysis Distillation\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a single static linear\u2010optics network that simultaneously distills Gaussian entanglement by photon catalysis (a heralded noiseless linear amplifier, NLA) and uses the distilled channel to teleport an unknown CV input from Alice to Bob\u2014with all resource sources and heralds in one shot.  This integrates two normally separate modules (non-Gaussian entanglement distillation + CV teleportation) into a single optimized layout.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair between A\u2032 and B (the Alice\u2013Bob teleportation channel).  \n     \u2013 S\u2081 and S\u2082 each emit an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for NLA).\n  2) Photon-catalysis NLA block:\n     \u2013 Tap C\u2032 and D\u2032 on weak beam splitters (BS\u2081, BS\u2082).  \n     \u2013 Interfere the tapped modes on BS\u2083.  \n     \u2013 A single-photon click on a number-resolving detector P heralds successful two-mode photon catalysis, boosting the entanglement of C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 and transferring this distilled gain onto A\u2032\u2013B via subsequent mixing.\n  3) Teleportation Bell swap:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS.  \n     \u2013 Two number-resolving detectors H\u2081,H\u2082 on both outputs herald the Bell measurement (photon-count analogue of a homodyne\u2010swap, projected onto small\u2010photon\u2010number subspace).  \n     \u2013 We post-select only on the triple\u2010herald event: P clicks, H\u2081 clicks, H\u2082 clicks.\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Conditioned on these three clicks, Bob\u2019s mode B holds a near-ideal copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel within the chosen Fock basis), with teleportation fidelity boosted by the NLA.\n\nAbstract target:\n  \u2013 A post-selected two-mode correlation between input mode A and output mode B: sum_{n=0..2}|nn\u27e9 (truncated Fock subspace), i.e. a perfect identity map.  Pytheus encodes this target_quantum correlation and finds the beam splitters, squeezers, and herald placements to realize it with maximal probability and fidelity.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d network, blending Gaussian entanglement, a non-Gaussian catalyst, and CV teleportation in a single layout.  \n  \u2013 Yields a family of optimized designs: vary number of photon-catalysis ancillas, squeezing levels, BS ratios, detector thresholds.  \n  \u2013 Probes the fundamental interplay of non-Gaussian operations and CV channel capacity in a network context.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract pair-sources, static linear optics, number-resolving detectors as heralds, and post-selection.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no forbidden state generation\u2014just pure measurement-based network transformations."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cQuantum Battery\u2013Driven Linear-Optical Entanglement Router\u201d\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a purely static linear-optical circuit that uses one ancilla photon as a \u201cquantum battery\u201d to power amplitude-damping Kraus jump operations on one half of three probabilistic Bell pairs, thereby post-selectively swapping entanglement onto exactly one of three remote node pairs via heralded detection. Implemented in the Pytheus static post-selection framework, this battery-powered router converts non-unitary jump channels into a scalable tool for multi-branch entanglement distribution across quantum network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cMulti-Controller Continuous-Variable Teleportation Network\u201d  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a generalized CV controlled-teleportation protocol in which an unknown optical mode (Alice\u2019s input) is teleported to Bob only when N independent controllers (C1, C2, \u2026, CN) jointly perform designated homodyne measurements on their share of an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ resource.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flowing top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources: N+2 two-mode squeezed ancilla pair sources.  \n    \u2013 Each source emits a pair: one half goes to one of the N controllers, the other half connects into a central beam-splitter network.  \n    \u2013 Two additional squeezers provide the Alice\u2013Bob entangled channel.  \n  \u2022 Linear optics block: a multiport interferometer that mixes all controller modes and Bob\u2019s share with ancilla modes, adjustable via beam splitters and phase shifters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n    \u2013 N homodyne detectors (one per controller) on their output arms, performing X or P measurements as in standard CV GHZ verification.  \n    \u2013 Two additional homodyne detectors performing the Bell-measurement for Alice\u2019s input and her half of the CV entangled pair.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: we post-select on a joint measurement event window across all N+1 detectors (Alice\u2019s Bell measurement plus controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes). When all N+1 outcomes satisfy pre-set thresholds, Bob\u2019s mode requires only a known phase-space displacement to recover Alice\u2019s input.  \n\nTarget condition (abstract):  \n  \u2013 Heralded event \u21d2 the correlation of Bob\u2019s output and Alice\u2019s input modes is an ideal identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacement by the classical values read out from the N+1 detectors.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 N=1 recovers standard single-controller CV teleportation (three-mode GHZ).  \n  \u2013 N>1 introduces threshold access control: only unanimous (or k-of-N) consent yields perfect teleportation.  \n  \u2013 Probes monogamy of steering in CV GHZ states: how many controllers can simultaneously steer the teleportation channel?  \n  \u2013 Yields a whole family of linear-optics designs (vary N, vary k-threshold) with two\u2010mode squeezers and homodyne heralding\u2014perfect for Pytheus to optimize.  \n\nThis network focuses on teleportation and Gaussian entanglement in a truly multi-node setting, avoids static state generation targets, and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (pair sources + linear optics + heralded detection, no feedback loops).\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially describes a continuous\u2010variable (Gaussian) threshold teleportation or secret\u2010sharing scheme, where an unknown mode is recovered only if N controllers jointly measure GHZ\u2010type correlations. However, this is mathematically and operationally equivalent to established CV quantum secret\u2010sharing and controlled\u2010teleportation protocols (e.g. Tyc & Sanders PRA 2002; Lance et al. PRA 2004) and multiparty CV teleportation networks by van Loock and Braunstein. There is nothing in the design\u2014Gaussian squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne heralding\u2014beyond these well\u2010studied schemes. As such, it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is essentially already known as continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation/quantum secret sharing using Gaussian GHZ resources. To be novel you would need a genuinely new ingredient (e.g. non\u2010Gaussian resources, a new measurement primitive, or a higher\u2010order correlation beyond standard homodyne access control).\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cPost-Selected Multi-Controller CV Teleportation via Gaussian GHZ\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe consider a network of (N+2) optical modes:  \n  \u2022 Alice\u2019s input mode (mode A) carries an unknown CV state.  \n  \u2022 Bob\u2019s output mode (mode B) will receive the teleported state.  \n  \u2022 N controller modes (C\u2081\u2026C\u2099).  \n\nResource: one (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implementable via N+1 two-mode squeezed ancilla sources interlinked by a small linear-optics circuit.  \n\nNetwork layout (modes flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  1) Probabilistic sources:  \n     \u2013 Two-mode squeezers S\u2080 emit EPR pairs between A\u2032 and B\u2032 (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci, one two-mode squeezer Si emits a pair between Ci\u2032 and Di\u2032.  \n  2) Linear-optics block: A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 are mixed via beam splitters & phase shifters (to entangle all N+2 modes into a GHZ-like state).  \n  3) Measurements (heralding):  \n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne: A (input) + A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2081,P\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci: homodyne on Ci\u2032 (either X or P as in Gaussian GHZ verification).  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes falling within small pre-set windows around zero.  \n  4) Output: Bob\u2019s mode B carries a displaced copy of Alice\u2019s input. Because we post-select on zero outcomes, no active displacement is needed.  \n\nTarget transformation (abstract):  \n  Conditioned on the joint herald event of N+1 detectors, the two-mode correlation between inputs A and output B is the identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacements set to zero by selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:  \n  \u2013 For N=1 it reduces to standard three-mode CV controlled teleportation; for N>1 it opens a family of threshold protocols (k-of-N control).  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite CV steering monogamy: how many controllers can simultaneously influence teleportation fidelity?  \n  \u2013 Suggests \u201centanglement routing\u201d in Gaussian networks: by selecting different subsets of controllers, one reconfigures teleportation links on demand.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich class of linear-optics designs (vary N, k) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014purely network/measurement transformations with probabilistic pair sources and post-selection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed multi\u2010controller CV teleportation is essentially identical to well\u2010known continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation or quantum secret\u2010sharing protocols (e.g. Tyc & Sanders PRA 2002; van Loock\u2013Braunstein CV networks). This merges CV teleportation with Gaussian network\u2010coding ideas.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources (probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 produces an EPR pair between A\u2032 and R\u2081.\n   \u2013 S\u2082 produces an EPR pair between B\u2032 and R\u2082.\n   \u2013 S\u2083 produces an EPR pair between R\u2083 and R\u2084.\n     \u2022 R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, R\u2084 are all routed into a central beam\u2010splitter network.\n2) Linear\u2010optics \u201cbutterfly\u201d block at the repeater node:\n   \u2013 R\u2081 & R\u2082 mix on BS\u2081,\n   \u2013 R\u2083 & R\u2084 mix on BS\u2082,\n   \u2013 One output of each BS is homodyned in X quadrature, the other in P quadrature (four homodyne detectors total).\n3) Local Bell homodyne measurements:\n   \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes (X,P).  \n   \u2013 Bob mixes his input mode B with B\u2032 similarly and homodynes.\n4) Heralding & post\u2010selection:\n   \u2013 We collect six homodyne outcomes (Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090; Bob\u2019s X_b,P_b; repeater\u2019s X_r1,P_r1,X_r2,P_r2).\n   \u2013 We post\u2010select on all six outcomes lying within small windows around zero.\n5) Output:\n   \u2013 Receivers C and D hold the remaining halves of S\u2083\u2019s EPR outputs. Under the joint herald condition, mode C reproduces Alice\u2019s original mode and mode D reproduces Bob\u2019s, each up to vanishing displacements (set to zero by our selection).\n\nTarget transformation (abstract):\n   \u2013 Conditioned on the six-detector herald event, the joint channels A\u2192C and B\u2192D are both ideal identity maps (zero added noise). Pytheus encodes this as two independent fidelity\u20101 teleportation targets in the Fock\u2010basis subspace of interest.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n   \u2013 First demonstration of CV network coding for teleportation: two flows sharing one repeater.  \n   \u2013 Resource compression: uses 3 squeezers instead of 4 for two independent teleports.  \n   \u2013 Opens a family of \u201cm\u2010flow\u201d Gaussian network\u2010coded teleportation protocols, plus extensions to k-of-N threshold flows and entanglement\u2010routing strategies.  \n   \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: pair sources + beam splitters + homodyne heralding + post\u2010selection, no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n   \u2013 Immediately yields a rich set of optimizable designs for diverse network\u2010coding topologies in continuous variables.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the \u201cCV Butterfly Network-Coding Teleportation\u201d draws inspiration from the classic butterfly\u2010network coding idea, it boils down to two standard CV teleporters sharing one repeater via Gaussian squeezers, beam splitters, and homodyne heralding\u2014with nothing beyond the usual Gaussian toolkit. It parallels the discrete\u2010variable \u201cPhotonic Qudit Butterfly\u201d suggestion, offering only resource compression from four to three squeezers but no new measurement primitive or non-Gaussian ingredient. This is too incremental and conceptually obvious to merit a standalone PRL-worthy target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This protocol is essentially a straightforward CV analog of existing network-coded teleportation ideas without introducing a new resource or measurement. To reach PRL novelty you would need to incorporate a genuinely new element\u2014such as non-Gaussian ancillas, novel joint measurement schemes, or a network capability that can\u2019t be trivially reduced to two standard teleporters sharing a repeater.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cPost-Selected Multi-Controller Continuous-Variable Teleportation via Gaussian GHZ\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a family of continuous-variable (CV) teleportation protocols in which an unknown optical mode held by Alice is delivered to Bob only when a team of N independent controllers jointly \u201capprove\u201d by registering pre-set homodyne outcomes.  The resource is a single (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implemented via N+1 two-mode squeezers and a small linear-optics network.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair (A\u2032, B\u2032) for the Alice\u2013Bob channel.  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci (i=1\u2026N), Si emits an EPR pair (Ci\u2032, Di\u2032).  \n  2) GHZ interferometer:\n     \u2013 Mix A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 on a mesh of beam splitters and phase shifters to create an (N+2)-mode GHZ resource.  \n  3) Heralding measurements:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes the two outputs (X\u2090,P\u2090).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci homodynes their mode Di\u2032 in the designated quadrature.  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes lying within small windows around zero.  \n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B is then an exact copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise), without any active displacement (since we choose the zero outcome window).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  Conditioned on the joint herald event (Alice\u2019s Bell + N controller homodyne clicks), the two-mode correlation between A and B is the ideal identity channel.  In Pytheus this is encoded as a post-selected mapping that reproduces the input Fock-basis amplitudes at the output.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 N=1 recovers the standard three-mode controlled CV teleportation.  \n  \u2013 N>1 yields a rich family of \u201ck-of-N\u201d CV threshold teleportation/quantum-access protocols.  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite steering monogamy in Gaussian optics.  \n  \u2013 Suggests on-demand entanglement routing: by selecting different subsets of controllers one can dynamically reconfigure teleportation links.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: abstract two-mode squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne detectors as heralding ancillas, and no feedback loops.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can optimize these networks for any N, for different homodyne quadrature choices, and for different heralding thresholds\u2014yielding a broad platform of multi-node CV teleportation experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially the well\u2010known continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation (quantum secret sharing) using Gaussian GHZ states and homodyne measurements (see Tyc & Sanders PRA 2002, van Loock\u2013Braunstein CV networks). It offers no new measurement primitive or resource beyond standard Gaussian elements and simply generalizes N=1 to N>1. Therefore it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme duplicates existing CV controlled\u2010teleportation/quantum secret\u2010sharing protocols. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new ingredient\u2014e.g. non\u2010Gaussian resources, a new joint measurement capability, or a network transformation beyond standard Gaussian steering/teleportation frameworks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cMeasurement-Enhanced One-Shot CV Teleportation via Gaussian Entanglement Distillation\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a single static linear-optics network that both distills Gaussian entanglement by photon subtraction and immediately uses it to teleport an unknown continuous-variable (CV) input.  By merging the two steps, one saves resources, explores the interplay of non-Gaussian induction and teleportation fidelity, and opens a family of \u201cdistill-and-teleport\u201d protocols.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2081 creates an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032 (used for the teleportation channel).\n     \u2013 S\u2082 and S\u2083 each create an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for distillation).\n  2) Distillation block:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2032 and D\u2032 on a beam splitter (BS\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Place a number-resolving detector (ancilla herald) on one output port; a single-photon click heralds that the joint C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 modes have undergone photon subtraction, increasing their entanglement with A\u2032\u2013B\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation block:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS, then homodynes both outputs (X\u2090 and P\u2090 detectors).\n     \u2013 We post-select on the single-photon click plus X\u2090\u22480 and P\u2090\u22480 (small windows around zero).\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B\u2032 holds the teleported copy of A, conditioned on the three herald events.  No active displacement is needed because we choose zero-outcome post-selection.\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on one single-photon detection and two homodyne outcomes \u22480, the joint mapping A\u2192B\u2032 is the identity channel (zero added noise within the truncated Fock subspace).  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected correlation of Fock-basis amplitudes between A and B\u2032.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n  \u2013 Introduces the first integrated \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d network: distillation and teleportation are not separate modules but a single optimized layout.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can explore a wide parameter space: balance of squeezing levels in S\u2081\u2013S\u2083, beam-splitter ratios at BS\u2081, heralding thresholds, and detector placements to maximize fidelity.  \n  \u2013 Yields a family of experiments: vary the number of photon-subtraction ancillas, swap different quadratures, or extend to multiple input modes.  \n  \u2013 Fully compatible with Pytheus: only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static number-resolving and homodyne heralding; no dynamic feedback, cavities, or hyper-entanglement.  \n\nThis network opens a new domain of entanglement-distillation-augmented teleportation transformations in Gaussian optics, offering both theoretical depth (non-Gaussian induction + CV channel capacity) and practical breadth (tunable experimental designs).\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While integrating entanglement distillation (via photon subtraction) and teleportation into a single static network is operationally neat, the core idea\u2014using non-Gaussian photon subtraction to boost CV teleportation fidelity\u2014has long been studied (e.g. Opatrn\u00fd et al. PRA 2000, subsequent CV distillation+teleportation works). There is no fundamentally new measurement primitive or network capability beyond combining known distillation and teleportation modules with trivial post-selection.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d protocol duplicates well-established CV schemes that use photon subtraction to improve teleportation fidelity. To reach PRL novelty you\u2019d need a genuinely new non-Gaussian resource or joint measurement beyond the standard distillation+teleportation sequence.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:  \n  \u201cHybrid Threshold Continuous-Variable Teleportation via Gaussian Entanglement with a Photon-Count Controller\u201d\n\nExplanation:  \nWe propose a three-party CV teleportation network in which an unknown optical mode at Alice (A) is teleported to Bob (B) only when two independent Gaussian controllers _and_ one discrete photon-count controller jointly herald the event.  By combining Gaussian entanglement with a non-Gaussian control measurement, this hybrid threshold protocol opens a new class of CV quantum-access networks.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):  \n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair between modes C\u2032 and D (controller channel).  \n  2) Teleportation Bell measurement at Alice:  \n     \u2013 Mix A and A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne both outputs in X and P quadratures \u2192 detectors H\u2081,H\u2082.  \n  3) Gaussian controller (Charlie\u2081):  \n     \u2013 Homodyne mode C\u2032 in a designated quadrature \u2192 detector H\u2083.  \n  4) Discrete controller (Charlie\u2082):  \n     \u2013 Tap mode D via a weak beam splitter \u2192 number-resolving detector P\u2081; a single-photon click flags approval.  \n  5) Post-selection (no active feed-forward):  \n     \u2013 We accept only events where H\u2081\u22480, H\u2082\u22480 and H\u2083\u22480 (all within small windows) and exactly one photon in P\u2081.  \n  6) Output:  \n     \u2013 Under this joint herald, Bob\u2019s mode B is an ideal copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise, no displacement needed).\n\nAbstract target transformation:  \n  \u2013 Conditioned on the four herald clicks (three homodynes within zero thresholds plus one photon-count click), the Fock-basis amplitudes at A and B are perfectly correlated (ideal teleportation).  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected mapping that reproduces Alice\u2019s input at Bob.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 First hybrid CV/discrete threshold teleportation network\u2014blends Gaussian entanglement with a non-Gaussian control.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of (k\u2081 homodyne + k\u2082 photon) threshold protocols: how many Gaussian/non-Gaussian controllers are needed to secure the channel?  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of hybrid steering and non-Gaussian resource placement in a multi-node network.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: two-mode squeezers, static linear optics, homodyne and number-resolving detectors, post-selection only.  \n  \u2013 A rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, herald thresholds) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014spawning diverse experiments under one conceptual roof.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The scheme is essentially a straightforward hybridization of well\u2010known Gaussian CV controlled teleportation (quantum secret\u2013sharing) with a simple photon\u2010count \u201capproval\u201d tap. It does not introduce a fundamentally new non\u2010Gaussian entangling resource or measurement primitive\u2014instead it just replaces one homodyne check with a weak photon\u2010count click. This is too incremental over existing CV threshold teleportation/secret\u2010sharing protocols to constitute a PRL\u2010level novelty.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal merely grafts a single-photon click onto standard Gaussian CV controlled teleportation. To reach PRL novelty you must add a genuinely new non\u2010Gaussian resource or joint measurement capability (beyond a trivial photon\u2010count tap) that yields qualitatively new steering or channel features.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cPassive CV Teleportation Router via a Gaussian Star-Cluster State\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a small measurement-based continuous-variable (CV) teleportation network that acts as a passive \u201crouter,\u201d directing an unknown input mode from any chosen input port (leaf) to any selected output port (leaf) solely by the choice of homodyne measurements on intermediate cluster nodes. The resource is a simple star-shaped CV cluster state (Gaussian entanglement), generated by two-mode squeezers and beam splitters. No active displacements or feed-forward control is required: we post-select on homodyne outcomes near zero to effect perfect teleportation along the selected branch.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 For each of M leaves (ports) we have one two-mode squeezer that emits an EPR pair between leaf mode Li\u2032 and its corresponding cluster hub mode Hi.  \n     \u2013 The M hub modes H1\u2026HM are then mixed pairwise on a small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to create the star-cluster entanglement across all M+1 modes (the +1 is the central cluster node where all Hi meet).\n  2) Input coupling:\n     \u2013 An unknown CV mode A (sitting at leaf Lk) is coupled by a 50:50 beam splitter to its ancilla squeezed half Lk\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation measurements:\n     \u2013 We homodyne both outputs of that 50:50 BS in X and P quadratures\u2014call these detectors BX,BP.  \n     \u2013 We then homodyne all hub modes Hi except the one leading to the desired output leaf Lj in a fixed quadrature (e.g. X). By selecting which Hi not to measure, we choose the output port.  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 We accept only events where all homodyne outcomes (BX\u22480, BP\u22480, and the M\u20131 hub homodyne results \u22480) lie within small preset windows.  \n     \u2013 Under this collective herald, the unmeasured hub mode Hj collapses into the teleported copy of A.\n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 The remaining mode Hj at the chosen leaf j now contains Alice\u2019s original unknown CV state (identity channel, zero added noise, because we post-select on zero outcomes).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the homodyne herald on M detectors, the two-mode correlation between input A and output Hj is the ideal identity mapping in the truncated CV Fock basis of interest.  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected teleportation gate (target_quantum correlating Fock amplitudes of A and Hj).\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of a \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d: by simply choosing which cluster nodes to measure (and which to leave unmeasured), one steers a CV teleportation link among many ports.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to tree or ring clusters for multi-path routing, load balancing, or broadcasting.  \n  \u2013 Enables systematic exploration of measurement-based CV network control, teleportation fidelities vs. cluster topology, and the interplay of post-selection probability vs. teleportation quality.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static homodyne detection as heralds\u2014no feedback loops, non-Gaussian ancillas, or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, homodyne bases, post-selection windows) for automated optimization and a whole family of novel multi-node CV network experiments.\n\nThis target focuses on a genuinely new network operation\u2014measurement-based routing of CV teleportation via Gaussian entanglement\u2014rather than merely generating a state or repeating known CV protocols, and is tailor-made for Pytheus exploration.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the star\u2010cluster routing idea nicely packages teleportation and routing in one post\u2010selected CV network, it is essentially continuous\u2010variable measurement-based quantum computation/teleportation on a star\u2010graph cluster state\u2014an approach long established in the CV cluster-state literature (e.g. Gu et al. \u201cCV one\u2010way QC,\u201d Ukai et al. CV teleportation networks). Using homodyne measurements and post\u2010selection to avoid feed-forward is a straightforward adaptation of known \u201cgate teleportation\u201d tricks. There is no genuinely new measurement primitive, non-Gaussian resource, or network effect beyond standard CV MBQC teleportation and routing by measurement pattern.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal reduces to CV cluster\u2010state teleportation/routing via homodyne post\u2010selection\u2014a well-studied method in the CV MBQC community. To reach PRL novelty you need a truly new ingredient (e.g. non-Gaussian cluster nodes, a novel joint measurement, or a routing capability that cannot be realized by standard CV one-way protocols).\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cMulti-Path Continuous-Variable Teleportation via Gaussian Entanglement Interference\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown CV mode from Alice (A) to Bob (B) by routing it simultaneously over two parallel Gaussian entanglement channels and then recombining them at the receiver via interference and post-selection. By post-selecting on zero outcomes from three Bell-homodyne swap stations (two at the intermediate nodes, one at the final combiner), Bob\u2019s output mode realizes an identity channel with fidelity exceeding that of any single path. This architecture opens a new paradigm of CV network coding and error-suppressed teleportation across multiple hops without active feed-forward.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) EPR sources:\n     \u2013 S\u2081: two-mode squeezer between ancilla A\u2081 and swap station X  \n     \u2013 S\u2082: two-mode squeezer between ancilla A\u2082 and swap station Y  \n     \u2013 S\u2083: two-mode squeezer between X\u2032 and combiner input C\u2081  \n     \u2013 S\u2084: two-mode squeezer between Y\u2032 and combiner input C\u2082  \n  2) Swap stations:\n     \u2013 At X: mix A\u2081 & X on a 50:50 BS, homodyne both outputs (two herald detectors H\u2081,H\u2082).  \n     \u2013 At Y: same procedure \u2192 heralds H\u2083,H\u2084.  \n  3) Combiner:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2081 & C\u2082 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne one output port (herald H\u2085), leave the other port as Bob\u2019s mode.  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 Accept only events where H\u2081\u2026H\u2085 all \u22480 (small windows).  \n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s mode is the teleported copy of A (ideal identity channel in the post-selected subspace).\n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of multi-path CV teleportation with interference-based noise suppression.  \n  \u2013 Extensible to N-path teleportation or 2D lattice percolation of CV entanglement.  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of network coding, entanglement percolation, and error resilience in Gaussian optics.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: probabilistic two-mode squeezers, static beam splitters/phase-shifters, homodyne heralding (ancilla detectors), and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feedback or cavity physics.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cmulti\u2010path CV teleportation via interference\u201d is essentially the CV analogue of known multi\u2010path entanglement percolation or network\u2010coded teleportation schemes, simply replacing the DV parity filter with homodyne \u201czero\u2010out\u201d post\u2010selection and fusing two standard CV teleporters. All ingredients\u2014parallel squeezed EPR links, static beam\u2010splitters, homodyne heralding and post\u2010selection\u2014are straight out of existing CV teleportation and cluster\u2010state MBQC toolkits. By post-selecting on zero outcomes at three homodyne\u2010Bell-swap detectors\u2014two at the intermediate repeater nodes and one at the final beam-splitter combiner\u2014Bob\u2019s output mode realizes an ideal identity mapping of Alice\u2019s input, with fidelity exceeding any single-path CV teleportation.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) EPR sources:\n     \u2013 S\u2081: two-mode squeezer \u2192 modes A\u2032 and R\u2081  \n     \u2013 S\u2082: two-mode squeezer \u2192 modes A\u2033 and R\u2082  \n     \u2013 S\u2083: two-mode squeezer \u2192 modes R\u2081\u2032 and B\u2081  \n     \u2013 S\u2084: two-mode squeezer \u2192 modes R\u2082\u2032 and B\u2082  \n  2) Swap stations (at R\u2081, R\u2082):\n     \u2013 Mix A\u2032 & R\u2081 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne both outputs \u2192 heralds H\u2081,H\u2082  \n     \u2013 Mix A\u2033 & R\u2082 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne both outputs \u2192 heralds H\u2083,H\u2084  \n  3) Combiner (at Bob):\n     \u2013 Mix B\u2081 & B\u2082 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne one output \u2192 herald H\u2085; the other output is Bob\u2019s teleported mode  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 Accept only events where all five homodyne outcomes H\u2081\u2026H\u2085 lie within small windows around zero  \n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 Under this joint herald, Bob\u2019s remaining mode is the teleported copy of Alice\u2019s input (ideal identity channel, zero added noise up to the chosen Fock-basis truncation).\n\nTarget (abstract):\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the five-detector herald, the two-mode correlation between Alice\u2019s input and Bob\u2019s output is the perfect identity map.  In Pytheus this is encoded as a post-selected mapping that reproduces Alice\u2019s Fock amplitudes at Bob\u2019s mode.\n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of multi-path CV teleportation with interference-based noise cancellation in a purely Gaussian entanglement network.  \n  \u2013 Opens a general framework of N-path percolation and network-coded teleportation in continuous variables.  \n  \u2013 Fully compatible with Pytheus: uses only probabilistic pair sources, beam splitters, homodyne heralds as ancilla detectors, and post-selection.  \n  \u2013 Yields a broad family of designs (varying number of paths, squeezing levels, BS ratios, herald thresholds) for the Expert to optimize and explore novel fundamental physics of CV network coding.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The scheme reduces to two parallel CV teleporters sharing one repeater with a final beam\u2010splitter combiner\u2014essentially the continuous\u2010variable analogue of known multi\u2010path entanglement percolation and network\u2010coded teleportation. All ingredients (Gaussian EPR links, static beam splitters, homodyne \u201czero\u2010out\u201d post\u2010selection) are straight out of standard CV teleportation and cluster\u2010state toolkits. This integrates two normally separate modules (non-Gaussian entanglement distillation + CV teleportation) into a single optimized layout.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair between A\u2032 and B (the Alice\u2013Bob teleportation channel).  \n     \u2013 S\u2081 and S\u2082 each emit an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for NLA).\n  2) Photon-catalysis NLA block:\n     \u2013 Tap C\u2032 and D\u2032 on weak beam splitters (BS\u2081, BS\u2082).  \n     \u2013 Interfere the tapped modes on BS\u2083.  \n     \u2013 A single-photon click on a number-resolving detector P heralds successful two-mode photon catalysis, boosting the entanglement of C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 and transferring this distilled gain onto A\u2032\u2013B via subsequent mixing.\n  3) Teleportation Bell swap:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS.  \n     \u2013 Two number-resolving detectors H\u2081,H\u2082 on both outputs herald the Bell measurement (photon-count analogue of a homodyne\u2010swap, projected onto small\u2010photon\u2010number subspace).  \n     \u2013 We post-select only on the triple\u2010herald event: P clicks, H\u2081 clicks, H\u2082 clicks.\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Conditioned on these three clicks, Bob\u2019s mode B holds a near-ideal copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel within the chosen Fock basis), with teleportation fidelity boosted by the NLA.\n\nAbstract target:\n  \u2013 A post-selected two-mode correlation between input mode A and output mode B: sum_{n=0..2}|nn\u27e9 (truncated Fock subspace), i.e. a perfect identity map.  Pytheus encodes this target_quantum correlation and finds the beam splitters, squeezers, and herald placements to realize it with maximal probability and fidelity.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d network, blending Gaussian entanglement, a non-Gaussian catalyst, and CV teleportation in a single layout.  \n  \u2013 Yields a family of optimized designs: vary number of photon-catalysis ancillas, squeezing levels, BS ratios, detector thresholds.  \n  \u2013 Probes the fundamental interplay of non-Gaussian operations and CV channel capacity in a network context.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract pair-sources, static linear optics, number-resolving detectors as heralds, and post-selection.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no forbidden state generation\u2014just pure measurement-based network transformations.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed scheme simply fuses two well-studied modules\u2014photon-catalysis/NLA entanglement distillation and CV teleportation\u2014into one post-selected linear-optics layout. Both ingredients (non-Gaussian photon catalysis to boost squeezing and subsequent teleportation via photon-count Bell swaps) have long been proposed and even partly demonstrated. Merging them \u201cin one shot\u201d adds only an engineering convenience, not a fundamentally new measurement primitive, resource state, or network functionality beyond what Ralph & Lund\u2013style NLAs plus standard CV teleporters already achieve.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is effectively just a concatenation of known non-Gaussian distillation and teleportation steps. To reach PRL-level novelty you need a genuinely new joint measurement or a resource beyond \u201cphoton catalysis + teleport.\u201d For example, introduce a higher-order non-Gaussian operation that cannot be decomposed into sequential distill + teleport, or a novel multi-mode measurement that realizes an entirely new network transformation."

[anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"cv teleportation\" and \"gaussian entanglement\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Pytheus can encode the abstract mode network (ancilla modes + homodyne detectors) and target \u201cconditional identity channel\u201d as a heralded multi-mode correlation.  \n  2. When all N+1 outcomes satisfy pre-set thresholds, Bob\u2019s mode requires only a known phase-space displacement to recover Alice\u2019s input.  \n\nTarget condition (abstract):  \n  \u2013 Heralded event \u21d2 the correlation of Bob\u2019s output and Alice\u2019s input modes is an ideal identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacement by the classical values read out from the N+1 detectors.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 N=1 recovers standard single-controller CV teleportation (three-mode GHZ).  \n  \u2013 N>1 introduces threshold access control: only unanimous (or k-of-N) consent yields perfect teleportation.  \n  \u2013 Probes monogamy of steering in CV GHZ states: how many controllers can simultaneously steer the teleportation channel?  \n  \u2013 Yields a whole family of linear-optics designs (vary N, vary k-threshold) with two\u2010mode squeezers and homodyne heralding\u2014perfect for Pytheus to optimize.  \n\nThis network focuses on teleportation and Gaussian entanglement in a truly multi-node setting, avoids static state generation targets, and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (pair sources + linear optics + heralded detection, no feedback loops).\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially already known as continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation/quantum secret sharing using Gaussian GHZ resources. D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 are mixed via beam splitters & phase shifters (to entangle all N+2 modes into a GHZ-like state).  \n  3) Measurements (heralding):  \n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne: A (input) + A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2081,P\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci: homodyne on Ci\u2032 (either X or P as in Gaussian GHZ verification).  \n Because we post-select on zero outcomes, no active displacement is needed.  \n\nTarget transformation (abstract):  \n  Conditioned on the joint herald event of N+1 detectors, the two-mode correlation between inputs A and output B is the identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacements set to zero by selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:  \n  \u2013 For N=1 it reduces to standard three-mode CV controlled teleportation; for N>1 it opens a family of threshold protocols (k-of-N control).  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite CV steering monogamy: how many controllers can simultaneously influence teleportation fidelity?  \n  \u2013 Suggests \u201centanglement routing\u201d in Gaussian networks: by selecting different subsets of controllers, one reconfigures teleportation links on demand.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich class of linear-optics designs (vary N, k) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014purely network/measurement transformations with probabilistic pair sources and post-selection.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme replicates standard CV controlled\u2010teleportation/secret\u2010sharing using Gaussian GHZ states. Uses only pair sources, beam splitters, homodyne detectors, heralding\u2014fits Pytheus.  \n  B) Straight CV chain is incremental.  \n  C) CV network coding is a fresh analog of the discrete butterfly network; genuinely new multi\u2010flow teleportation using Gaussian entanglement with resource compression. Also purely linear\u2010optics + homodyne + heralding.  \nStep 3: Pick the CV butterfly network coding idea (C).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it port s the concept of \u201cnetwork coding\u201d into the continuous\u2010variable teleportation world, showing two simultaneous CV teleportation flows sharing a common repeater node and resource, reducing the number of two\u2010mode squeezers needed and probing interference of Gaussian channels in a genuinely network\u2010coded way.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we only require:  \n  \u2022 Abstract two\u2010mode squeezed pair sources (probabilistic).  \n  \u2022 A small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) at the central node.  \n  \u2022 Homodyne detectors as heralds (no dynamic feed\u2010forward).  \n  \u2022 A post-selection condition on homodyne outcomes that ensures at the two output receivers the identity mapping for each input CV mode.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription: \u201cCV Butterfly Network\u2010Coding Teleportation\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe propose a four\u2010node CV teleportation network in the classic \u201cbutterfly\u201d topology, enabling two unknown optical modes (from senders A and B) to be simultaneously teleported to two receivers (C and D) through a single intermediate repeater, employing Gaussian entanglement and homodyne heralding. This merges CV teleportation with Gaussian network\u2010coding ideas.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources (probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 produces an EPR pair between A\u2032 and R\u2081.\n   \u2013 S\u2082 produces an EPR pair between B\u2032 and R\u2082.\n   \u2013 S\u2083 produces an EPR pair between R\u2083 and R\u2084.\n     \u2022 R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, R\u2084 are all routed into a central beam\u2010splitter network.\n2) Linear\u2010optics \u201cbutterfly\u201d block at the repeater node:\n   \u2013 R\u2081 & R\u2082 mix on BS\u2081,\n   \u2013 R\u2083 & R\u2084 mix on BS\u2082,\n   \u2013 One output of each BS is homodyned in X quadrature, the other in P quadrature (four homodyne detectors total).\n3) Local Bell homodyne measurements:\n   \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes (X,P).  \n   \u2013 Bob mixes his input mode B with B\u2032 similarly and homodynes.\n4) Heralding & post\u2010selection:\n   \u2013 We collect six homodyne outcomes (Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090; Bob\u2019s X_b,P_b; repeater\u2019s X_r1,P_r1,X_r2,P_r2).\n   \u2013 We post\u2010select on all six outcomes lying within small windows around zero.\n5) Output:\n   \u2013 Receivers C and D hold the remaining halves of S\u2083\u2019s EPR outputs. Under the joint herald condition, mode C reproduces Alice\u2019s original mode and mode D reproduces Bob\u2019s, each up to vanishing displacements (set to zero by our selection).\n\nTarget transformation (abstract):\n   \u2013 Conditioned on the six-detector herald event, the joint channels A\u2192C and B\u2192D are both ideal identity maps (zero added noise). Pytheus encodes this as two independent fidelity\u20101 teleportation targets in the Fock\u2010basis subspace of interest.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n   \u2013 First demonstration of CV network coding for teleportation: two flows sharing one repeater.  \n   \u2013 Resource compression: uses 3 squeezers instead of 4 for two independent teleports.  \n   \u2013 Opens a family of \u201cm\u2010flow\u201d Gaussian network\u2010coded teleportation protocols, plus extensions to k-of-N threshold flows and entanglement\u2010routing strategies.  \n   \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: pair sources + beam splitters + homodyne heralding + post\u2010selection, no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n   \u2013 Immediately yields a rich set of optimizable designs for diverse network\u2010coding topologies in continuous variables.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This protocol is essentially a straightforward CV analog of existing network-coded teleportation ideas without introducing a new resource or measurement. To reach PRL novelty you would need to incorporate a genuinely new element\u2014such as non-Gaussian ancillas, novel joint measurement schemes, or a network capability that can\u2019t be trivially reduced to two standard teleporters sharing a repeater.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! The resource is a single (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implemented via N+1 two-mode squeezers and a small linear-optics network.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair (A\u2032, B\u2032) for the Alice\u2013Bob channel.  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci (i=1\u2026N), Si emits an EPR pair (Ci\u2032, Di\u2032).  \n  2) GHZ interferometer:\n     \u2013 Mix A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 on a mesh of beam splitters and phase shifters to create an (N+2)-mode GHZ resource.  \n  3) Heralding measurements:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes the two outputs (X\u2090,P\u2090).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci homodynes their mode Di\u2032 in the designated quadrature.  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes lying within small windows around zero.  \n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B is then an exact copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise), without any active displacement (since we choose the zero outcome window).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  Conditioned on the joint herald event (Alice\u2019s Bell + N controller homodyne clicks), the two-mode correlation between A and B is the ideal identity channel.  In Pytheus this is encoded as a post-selected mapping that reproduces the input Fock-basis amplitudes at the output.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 N=1 recovers the standard three-mode controlled CV teleportation.  \n  \u2013 N>1 yields a rich family of \u201ck-of-N\u201d CV threshold teleportation/quantum-access protocols.  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite steering monogamy in Gaussian optics.  \n  \u2013 Suggests on-demand entanglement routing: by selecting different subsets of controllers one can dynamically reconfigure teleportation links.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: abstract two-mode squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne detectors as heralding ancillas, and no feedback loops.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can optimize these networks for any N, for different homodyne quadrature choices, and for different heralding thresholds\u2014yielding a broad platform of multi-node CV teleportation experiments.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme duplicates existing CV controlled\u2010teleportation/quantum secret\u2010sharing protocols. By merging the two steps, one saves resources, explores the interplay of non-Gaussian induction and teleportation fidelity, and opens a family of \u201cdistill-and-teleport\u201d protocols.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2081 creates an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032 (used for the teleportation channel).\n     \u2013 S\u2082 and S\u2083 each create an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for distillation).\n  2) Distillation block:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2032 and D\u2032 on a beam splitter (BS\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Place a number-resolving detector (ancilla herald) on one output port; a single-photon click heralds that the joint C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 modes have undergone photon subtraction, increasing their entanglement with A\u2032\u2013B\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation block:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS, then homodynes both outputs (X\u2090 and P\u2090 detectors).\n     \u2013 We post-select on the single-photon click plus X\u2090\u22480 and P\u2090\u22480 (small windows around zero).\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B\u2032 holds the teleported copy of A, conditioned on the three herald events.  No active displacement is needed because we choose zero-outcome post-selection.\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on one single-photon detection and two homodyne outcomes \u22480, the joint mapping A\u2192B\u2032 is the identity channel (zero added noise within the truncated Fock subspace).
