Pytheus can optimize a network of squeezers, beam splitters, and homodyne detectors with post-selection\u2014no feedback loops or cavities needed.\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\nStep 4: Novelty:  \n  \u2013 Introduces the first \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d network that uses a small Gaussian cluster state as a switch: by choosing which intermediate cluster node(s) to homodyne and post-selecting on zero outcomes, one routes an unknown CV mode from any input leaf to any desired output leaf.  \n  \u2013 Opens a broad family of CV entanglement-routing protocols: star, tree, ring, where measurement patterns alone steer the teleportation path.  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of measurement-based CV network control in a static linear-optics layout.\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n  \u2013 Only uses abstract two-mode squeezers (probabilistic pair sources), a static interferometer of beam splitters & phase shifters to build the cluster, and homodyne detectors as heralds (ancilla detectors) with post-selection windows.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement \u2014 all within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cPassive CV Teleportation Router via a Gaussian Star-Cluster State\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a small measurement-based continuous-variable (CV) teleportation network that acts as a passive \u201crouter,\u201d directing an unknown input mode from any chosen input port (leaf) to any selected output port (leaf) solely by the choice of homodyne measurements on intermediate cluster nodes. The resource is a simple star-shaped CV cluster state (Gaussian entanglement), generated by two-mode squeezers and beam splitters. No active displacements or feed-forward control is required: we post-select on homodyne outcomes near zero to effect perfect teleportation along the selected branch.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 For each of M leaves (ports) we have one two-mode squeezer that emits an EPR pair between leaf mode Li\u2032 and its corresponding cluster hub mode Hi.  \n     \u2013 The M hub modes H1\u2026HM are then mixed pairwise on a small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to create the star-cluster entanglement across all M+1 modes (the +1 is the central cluster node where all Hi meet).\n  2) Input coupling:\n     \u2013 An unknown CV mode A (sitting at leaf Lk) is coupled by a 50:50 beam splitter to its ancilla squeezed half Lk\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation measurements:\n     \u2013 We homodyne both outputs of that 50:50 BS in X and P quadratures\u2014call these detectors BX,BP.  \n     \u2013 We then homodyne all hub modes Hi except the one leading to the desired output leaf Lj in a fixed quadrature (e.g. X). By selecting which Hi not to measure, we choose the output port.  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 We accept only events where all homodyne outcomes (BX\u22480, BP\u22480, and the M\u20131 hub homodyne results \u22480) lie within small preset windows.  \n     \u2013 Under this collective herald, the unmeasured hub mode Hj collapses into the teleported copy of A.\n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 The remaining mode Hj at the chosen leaf j now contains Alice\u2019s original unknown CV state (identity channel, zero added noise, because we post-select on zero outcomes).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the homodyne herald on M detectors, the two-mode correlation between input A and output Hj is the ideal identity mapping in the truncated CV Fock basis of interest.  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected teleportation gate (target_quantum correlating Fock amplitudes of A and Hj).\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of a \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d: by simply choosing which cluster nodes to measure (and which to leave unmeasured), one steers a CV teleportation link among many ports.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to tree or ring clusters for multi-path routing, load balancing, or broadcasting.  \n  \u2013 Enables systematic exploration of measurement-based CV network control, teleportation fidelities vs. cluster topology, and the interplay of post-selection probability vs. teleportation quality.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static homodyne detection as heralds\u2014no feedback loops, non-Gaussian ancillas, or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, homodyne bases, post-selection windows) for automated optimization and a whole family of novel multi-node CV network experiments.\n\nThis target focuses on a genuinely new network operation\u2014measurement-based routing of CV teleportation via Gaussian entanglement\u2014rather than merely generating a state or repeating known CV protocols, and is tailor-made for Pytheus exploration.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal reduces to CV cluster\u2010state teleportation/routing via homodyne post\u2010selection\u2014a well-studied method in the CV MBQC community. To reach PRL novelty you need a truly new ingredient (e.g. non-Gaussian cluster nodes, a novel joint measurement, or a routing capability that cannot be realized by standard CV one-way protocols).\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! By post-selecting on zero outcomes from three Bell-homodyne swap stations (two at the intermediate nodes, one at the final combiner), Bob\u2019s output mode realizes an identity channel with fidelity exceeding that of any single path. This architecture opens a new paradigm of CV network coding and error-suppressed teleportation across multiple hops without active feed-forward.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) EPR sources:\n     \u2013 S\u2081: two-mode squeezer between ancilla A\u2081 and swap station X  \n     \u2013 S\u2082: two-mode squeezer between ancilla A\u2082 and swap station Y  \n     \u2013 S\u2083: two-mode squeezer between X\u2032 and combiner input C\u2081  \n     \u2013 S\u2084: two-mode squeezer between Y\u2032 and combiner input C\u2082  \n  2) Swap stations:\n     \u2013 At X: mix A\u2081 & X on a 50:50 BS, homodyne both outputs (two herald detectors H\u2081,H\u2082).  \n     \u2013 At Y: same procedure \u2192 heralds H\u2083,H\u2084.  \n  3) Combiner:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2081 & C\u2082 on a 50:50 BS; This integrates two normally separate modules (non-Gaussian entanglement distillation + CV teleportation) into a single optimized layout.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair between A\u2032 and B (the Alice\u2013Bob teleportation channel).  \n     \u2013 S\u2081 and S\u2082 each emit an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for NLA).\n  2) Photon-catalysis NLA block:\n     \u2013 Tap C\u2032 and D\u2032 on weak beam splitters (BS\u2081, BS\u2082).  \n     \u2013 Interfere the tapped modes on BS\u2083.  \n     \u2013 A single-photon click on a number-resolving detector P heralds successful two-mode photon catalysis, boosting the entanglement of C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 and transferring this distilled gain onto A\u2032\u2013B via subsequent mixing.\n  3) Teleportation Bell swap:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS.  \n     \u2013 Two number-resolving detectors H\u2081,H\u2082 on both outputs herald the Bell measurement (photon-count analogue of a homodyne\u2010swap, projected onto small\u2010photon\u2010number subspace).  \n     \u2013 We post-select only on the triple\u2010herald event: P clicks, H\u2081 clicks, H\u2082 clicks.\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Conditioned on these three clicks, Bob\u2019s mode B holds a near-ideal copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel within the chosen Fock basis), with teleportation fidelity boosted by the NLA.\n\nAbstract target:\n  \u2013 A post-selected two-mode correlation between input mode A and output mode B: sum_{n=0..2}|nn\u27e9 (truncated Fock subspace), i.e. a perfect identity map.  Pytheus encodes this target_quantum correlation and finds the beam splitters, squeezers, and herald placements to realize it with maximal probability and fidelity.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d network, blending Gaussian entanglement, a non-Gaussian catalyst, and CV teleportation in a single layout.  \n  \u2013 Yields a family of optimized designs: vary number of photon-catalysis ancillas, squeezing levels, BS ratios, detector thresholds.  \n  \u2013 Probes the fundamental interplay of non-Gaussian operations and CV channel capacity in a network context.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract pair-sources, static linear optics, number-resolving detectors as heralds, and post-selection.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no forbidden state generation\u2014just pure measurement-based network transformations.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively just a concatenation of known non-Gaussian distillation and teleportation steps.     "output": "Description:\n  \u201cMeasurement\u2010Programmed Continuous\u2010Variable Teleportation Switch via a Gaussian Star\u2010Cluster\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a purely measurement\u2010driven network that routes an unknown CV optical mode from any chosen input port to any selected output port, using only Gaussian entanglement and post\u2010selected homodyne measurements in a single static linear\u2010optics layout.  By reinterpreting the star\u2010cluster concept from CV one\u2010way quantum computing as a teleportation \u201cswitch,\u201d we open a novel family of CV network routing protocols that require no active feed\u2010forward or dynamic elements\u2014only probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers, beam splitters, and homodyne detectors with post\u2010selection windows.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  1) Resource generation:\n     \u2013 For each of M leaf ports i=1\u2026M we place a two\u2010mode squeezer Si producing an EPR pair between leaf mode Li\u2032 and hub mode Hi.  \n     \u2013 All M hub modes H1\u2026HM are then interfered pairwise on a small static beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shifter network to form an (M+1)\u2010mode Gaussian star\u2010cluster (the \u201c+1\u201d being the central node where all Hi meet).\n\n  2) Input coupling:\n     \u2013 Suppose we wish to teleport from input port k.  The unknown input mode A is combined with the corresponding squeezed half Lk\u2032 on a 50:50 beam splitter, and both outputs are homodyned in X and P quadratures (detectors D\u2081,D\u2082).\n\n  3) Routing measurements:\n     \u2013 To steer the teleportation to a target output port j, we homodyne all hub modes Hi except Hj in a fixed quadrature (e.g. X), recording outcomes at detectors D\u2083\u2026D_{M+1}.  The one unmeasured Hj becomes the output mode.\n\n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 We only accept events where all homodyne outcomes (D\u2081\u2026D_{M+1}) lie within small pre-set windows around zero.  Under this joint herald, the unmeasured mode Hj collapses to the teleported copy of A (identity channel with zero added noise, since we post-select on zero outcomes).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the M+1 homodyne heralds, the two\u2010mode joint Fock-basis correlation between A and the unmeasured Hj is the perfect identity mapping.  In Pytheus we encode this as a post-selected teleportation gate that reproduces the input\u2019s Fock amplitudes at the chosen output port.\n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research program:\n  \u2022 Measurement\u2010programmed routing: by simply choosing which cluster nodes to homodyne (and which to leave unmeasured), one dynamically reconfigures teleportation links in a multi-leaf network.  \n  \u2022 No active switching or displacement: the entire operation is passive and heralded, relying on a single static interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Extensible topologies: from star to tree or mesh clusters for multi-path routing, broadcasting, or load balancing of CV channels.  \n  \u2022 Foundational tests: probes how post-selection on Gaussian measurement patterns shapes teleportation fidelity vs. network size and geometry.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: only probabilistic two-mode squeezers, beam splitters/phase shifters, and homodyne detectors as ancilla heralds\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, non-Gaussian resources, or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Rich design space: Pytheus can optimize the number of squeezers, interferometer parameters, and heralding windows for arbitrary M, yielding a broad suite of novel multi-node CV teleportation routing experiments.\n\nThis proposal focuses on a genuinely new network operation\u2014passive, measurement\u2010driven CV teleportation routing via Gaussian entanglement\u2014avoiding forbidden state\u2010generation targets and leveraging Pytheus\u2019s strengths in abstract linear\u2010optics network synthesis."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"cv teleportation\" and \"gaussian entanglement\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. N-party controlled CV teleportation: use an (N+1)-mode Gaussian GHZ state to teleport a qumode from Alice to Bob only if all N controllers cooperatively measure their modes.  \n  2. Cascaded CV entanglement swapping chain: two independent two-mode squeezed sources link four parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D so that A and D become EPR-entangled by successive Bell-homodyne measurements, exploring noise build-up.  \n  3. CV teleportation ring: three nodes in a loop share three two-mode squeezers arranged in a triangle; an unknown CV input at A is teleported A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A in one shot, probing phase\u2010space \u201cholonomy.\u201d  \nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles.  \n  1. Controlled CV teleportation with more than one controller has been theorized only sparsely; discrete multi-controller is known, but full CV version with Gaussian GHZ and homodyne Bell measurements in linear optics has not been demonstrated. Pytheus can encode the abstract mode network (ancilla modes + homodyne detectors) and target \u201cconditional identity channel\u201d as a heralded multi-mode correlation.  \n  2. CV entanglement swapping is textbook; chaining two swaps adds little novelty.  \n  3. The teleportation ring is exotic conceptually but requires phase-space holonomy which is not obvious to encode as a final state target in Pytheus.  \nStep 3: Pick the multi-controller CV teleportation (idea 1).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because controlled teleportation in the continuous-variable regime has so far only been studied for a single controller (a three-mode Gaussian GHZ). Generalizing to N controllers opens a family of protocols\u2014quantum access control, threshold teleportation, and multipartite steering monogamy in a CV network.  \nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we can define an abstract (N+2)-mode target correlation: when all controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes fall into a given window (heralded events), the remaining two modes (Alice\u2019s output and Bob\u2019s output) must share perfect displacement\u2010corrected identity mapping of the input CV state. Pytheus can search for a linear\u2010optics network of two-mode squeezers (abstract ancilla pair sources), beam splitters, homodyne detectors (heralding), and classical feed-forward labels (heralded outputs), without requiring dynamic feedback or cavities.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription: \u201cMulti-Controller Continuous-Variable Teleportation Network\u201d  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a generalized CV controlled-teleportation protocol in which an unknown optical mode (Alice\u2019s input) is teleported to Bob only when N independent controllers (C1, C2, \u2026, CN) jointly perform designated homodyne measurements on their share of an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ resource.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flowing top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources: N+2 two-mode squeezed ancilla pair sources.  \n    \u2013 Each source emits a pair: one half goes to one of the N controllers, the other half connects into a central beam-splitter network.  \n    \u2013 Two additional squeezers provide the Alice\u2013Bob entangled channel.  \n  \u2022 Linear optics block: a multiport interferometer that mixes all controller modes and Bob\u2019s share with ancilla modes, adjustable via beam splitters and phase shifters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n    \u2013 N homodyne detectors (one per controller) on their output arms, performing X or P measurements as in standard CV GHZ verification.  \n    \u2013 Two additional homodyne detectors performing the Bell-measurement for Alice\u2019s input and her half of the CV entangled pair.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: we post-select on a joint measurement event window across all N+1 detectors (Alice\u2019s Bell measurement plus controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes). When all N+1 outcomes satisfy pre-set thresholds, Bob\u2019s mode requires only a known phase-space displacement to recover Alice\u2019s input.  \n\nTarget condition (abstract):  \n  \u2013 Heralded event \u21d2 the correlation of Bob\u2019s output and Alice\u2019s input modes is an ideal identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacement by the classical values read out from the N+1 detectors.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 N=1 recovers standard single-controller CV teleportation (three-mode GHZ).  \n  \u2013 N>1 introduces threshold access control: only unanimous (or k-of-N) consent yields perfect teleportation.  \n  \u2013 Probes monogamy of steering in CV GHZ states: how many controllers can simultaneously steer the teleportation channel?  \n  \u2013 Yields a whole family of linear-optics designs (vary N, vary k-threshold) with two\u2010mode squeezers and homodyne heralding\u2014perfect for Pytheus to optimize.  \n\nThis network focuses on teleportation and Gaussian entanglement in a truly multi-node setting, avoids static state generation targets, and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (pair sources + linear optics + heralded detection, no feedback loops).\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially already known as continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation/quantum secret sharing using Gaussian GHZ resources. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry CV teleportation with Gaussian entanglement in a Pytheus-compatible, multi-node network (no state-generation target, only teleportation/swapping transformations).  \n  1) \u201cN-Controller Post-Selected CV Teleportation\u201d: an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ resource is shared between Alice (input), Bob (output), and N controllers. By post-selecting on all N controller homodyne outcomes (plus Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne), Alice\u2019s unknown mode is teleported to Bob.  \n  2) \u201cCV Entanglement Swapping Chain with Dual Repeaters\u201d: two independent two-mode squeezed links A\u2013R1 and R2\u2013B, plus a third link R1\u2013R2; R1 and R2 perform homodyne Bell-measurements in tandem, heralding an EPR link A\u2013B. One studies routed CV entanglement over two hops without active feed-forward.  \n  3) \u201cMultiplexed Dual-Mode CV Teleportation\u201d: simultaneously teleport two independent CV modes from Alice1,2 to Bob1,2 using only three two-mode squeezers (rather than four) by a clever linear-optics network and four homodyne detectors, post-selecting on a joint measurement window.  \n\nStep 2: Compare novelty & Pytheus feasibility.  \n  1) N-Controller CV teleportation is known for N=1 but has not been ported to post-selected, multi-controller scenarios. It directly targets a teleportation transformation (identity channel) and uses only squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne detectors, and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n  2) Chaining two CV swaps is incremental, lacks fresh physics.  \n  3) Multiplexed teleportation with resource compression is interesting but more intricate to encode and its physics novelty is marginal compared to the controlled-teleportation network.  \n\nStep 3: Choose idea (1).  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because controlled continuous-variable teleportation beyond a single controller (N>1) has not been realized in a post-selected linear-optics setting. It yields a whole family of \u201ck-of-N\u201d threshold teleportation protocols, new tests of CV steering monogamy, and network-routing concepts in Gaussian optics.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because we only require:  \n  \u2022 Abstract two-mode squeezed sources (probabilistic pair sources).  \n  \u2022 A fixed interferometer of beam splitters & phase shifters mixing N controller arms + Alice\u2019s Bell port + Bob\u2019s GHZ port.  \n  \u2022 Homodyne detectors treated as heralding \u201cancilla detectors\u201d with post-selection windows (no dynamic feedback).  \n  \u2022 A target transformation: conditioned on N+1 herald clicks (Alice\u2019s Bell + N controllers within thresholds), Bob\u2019s output mode reproduces Alice\u2019s input (identity mapping).  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription: \u201cPost-Selected Multi-Controller CV Teleportation via Gaussian GHZ\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe consider a network of (N+2) optical modes:  \n  \u2022 Alice\u2019s input mode (mode A) carries an unknown CV state.  \n  \u2022 Bob\u2019s output mode (mode B) will receive the teleported state.  \n  \u2022 N controller modes (C\u2081\u2026C\u2099).  \n\nResource: one (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implementable via N+1 two-mode squeezed ancilla sources interlinked by a small linear-optics circuit.  \n\nNetwork layout (modes flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  1) Probabilistic sources:  \n     \u2013 Two-mode squeezers S\u2080 emit EPR pairs between A\u2032 and B\u2032 (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci, one two-mode squeezer Si emits a pair between Ci\u2032 and Di\u2032.  \n  2) Linear-optics block: A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 are mixed via beam splitters & phase shifters (to entangle all N+2 modes into a GHZ-like state).  \n  3) Measurements (heralding):  \n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne: A (input) + A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2081,P\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci: homodyne on Ci\u2032 (either X or P as in Gaussian GHZ verification).  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes falling within small pre-set windows around zero.  \n  4) Output: Bob\u2019s mode B carries a displaced copy of Alice\u2019s input. Because we post-select on zero outcomes, no active displacement is needed.  \n\nTarget transformation (abstract):  \n  Conditioned on the joint herald event of N+1 detectors, the two-mode correlation between inputs A and output B is the identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacements set to zero by selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:  \n  \u2013 For N=1 it reduces to standard three-mode CV controlled teleportation; for N>1 it opens a family of threshold protocols (k-of-N control).  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite CV steering monogamy: how many controllers can simultaneously influence teleportation fidelity?  \n  \u2013 Suggests \u201centanglement routing\u201d in Gaussian networks: by selecting different subsets of controllers, one reconfigures teleportation links on demand.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich class of linear-optics designs (vary N, k) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014purely network/measurement transformations with probabilistic pair sources and post-selection.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme replicates standard CV controlled\u2010teleportation/secret\u2010sharing using Gaussian GHZ states. This merges CV teleportation with Gaussian network\u2010coding ideas.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources (probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 produces an EPR pair between A\u2032 and R\u2081.\n   \u2013 S\u2082 produces an EPR pair between B\u2032 and R\u2082.\n   \u2013 S\u2083 produces an EPR pair between R\u2083 and R\u2084.\n     \u2022 R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, R\u2084 are all routed into a central beam\u2010splitter network.\n2) Linear\u2010optics \u201cbutterfly\u201d block at the repeater node:\n   \u2013 R\u2081 & R\u2082 mix on BS\u2081,\n   \u2013 R\u2083 & R\u2084 mix on BS\u2082,\n   \u2013 One output of each BS is homodyned in X quadrature, the other in P quadrature (four homodyne detectors total).\n3) Local Bell homodyne measurements:\n   \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes (X,P).  \n   \u2013 Bob mixes his input mode B with B\u2032 similarly and homodynes.\n4) Heralding & post\u2010selection:\n   \u2013 We collect six homodyne outcomes (Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090; Bob\u2019s X_b,P_b; repeater\u2019s X_r1,P_r1,X_r2,P_r2).\n   \u2013 We post\u2010select on all six outcomes lying within small windows around zero.\n5) Output:\n   \u2013 Receivers C and D hold the remaining halves of S\u2083\u2019s EPR outputs. Under the joint herald condition, mode C reproduces Alice\u2019s original mode and mode D reproduces Bob\u2019s, each up to vanishing displacements (set to zero by our selection).\n\nTarget transformation (abstract):\n   \u2013 Conditioned on the six-detector herald event, the joint channels A\u2192C and B\u2192D are both ideal identity maps (zero added noise). Pytheus encodes this as two independent fidelity\u20101 teleportation targets in the Fock\u2010basis subspace of interest.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n   \u2013 First demonstration of CV network coding for teleportation: two flows sharing one repeater.  \n   \u2013 Resource compression: uses 3 squeezers instead of 4 for two independent teleports.  \n   \u2013 Opens a family of \u201cm\u2010flow\u201d Gaussian network\u2010coded teleportation protocols, plus extensions to k-of-N threshold flows and entanglement\u2010routing strategies.  \n   \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: pair sources + beam splitters + homodyne heralding + post\u2010selection, no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n   \u2013 Immediately yields a rich set of optimizable designs for diverse network\u2010coding topologies in continuous variables.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This protocol is essentially a straightforward CV analog of existing network-coded teleportation ideas without introducing a new resource or measurement. By merging the two steps, one saves resources, explores the interplay of non-Gaussian induction and teleportation fidelity, and opens a family of \u201cdistill-and-teleport\u201d protocols.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2081 creates an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032 (used for the teleportation channel).\n     \u2013 S\u2082 and S\u2083 each create an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for distillation).\n  2) Distillation block:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2032 and D\u2032 on a beam splitter (BS\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Place a number-resolving detector (ancilla herald) on one output port; a single-photon click heralds that the joint C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 modes have undergone photon subtraction, increasing their entanglement with A\u2032\u2013B\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation block:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS, then homodynes both outputs (X\u2090 and P\u2090 detectors).\n     \u2013 We post-select on the single-photon click plus X\u2090\u22480 and P\u2090\u22480 (small windows around zero).\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B\u2032 holds the teleported copy of A, conditioned on the three herald events. By combining Gaussian entanglement with a non-Gaussian control measurement, this hybrid threshold protocol opens a new class of CV quantum-access networks.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):  \n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair between modes C\u2032 and D (controller channel).  \n  2) Teleportation Bell measurement at Alice:  \n     \u2013 Mix A and A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne both outputs in X and P quadratures \u2192 detectors H\u2081,H\u2082.  \n  3) Gaussian controller (Charlie\u2081):  \n     \u2013 Homodyne mode C\u2032 in a designated quadrature \u2192 detector H\u2083.  \n  4) Discrete controller (Charlie\u2082):  \n     \u2013 Tap mode D via a weak beam splitter \u2192 number-resolving detector P\u2081; a single-photon click flags approval.  \n  5) Post-selection (no active feed-forward):  \n     \u2013 We accept only events where H\u2081\u22480, H\u2082\u22480 and H\u2083\u22480 (all within small windows) and exactly one photon in P\u2081.  \n  6) Output:  \n     \u2013 Under this joint herald, Bob\u2019s mode B is an ideal copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise, no displacement needed).\n\nAbstract target transformation:  \n  \u2013 Conditioned on the four herald clicks (three homodynes within zero thresholds plus one photon-count click), the Fock-basis amplitudes at A and B are perfectly correlated (ideal teleportation).  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected mapping that reproduces Alice\u2019s input at Bob.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 First hybrid CV/discrete threshold teleportation network\u2014blends Gaussian entanglement with a non-Gaussian control.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of (k\u2081 homodyne + k\u2082 photon) threshold protocols: how many Gaussian/non-Gaussian controllers are needed to secure the channel?  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of hybrid steering and non-Gaussian resource placement in a multi-node network.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: two-mode squeezers, static linear optics, homodyne and number-resolving detectors, post-selection only.  \n  \u2013 A rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, herald thresholds) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014spawning diverse experiments under one conceptual roof.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal merely grafts a single-photon click onto standard Gaussian CV controlled teleportation. The resource is a simple star-shaped CV cluster state (Gaussian entanglement), generated by two-mode squeezers and beam splitters. No active displacements or feed-forward control is required: we post-select on homodyne outcomes near zero to effect perfect teleportation along the selected branch.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 For each of M leaves (ports) we have one two-mode squeezer that emits an EPR pair between leaf mode Li\u2032 and its corresponding cluster hub mode Hi.  \n     \u2013 The M hub modes H1\u2026HM are then mixed pairwise on a small interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to create the star-cluster entanglement across all M+1 modes (the +1 is the central cluster node where all Hi meet).\n  2) Input coupling:\n     \u2013 An unknown CV mode A (sitting at leaf Lk) is coupled by a 50:50 beam splitter to its ancilla squeezed half Lk\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation measurements:\n     \u2013 We homodyne both outputs of that 50:50 BS in X and P quadratures\u2014call these detectors BX,BP.  \n     \u2013 We then homodyne all hub modes Hi except the one leading to the desired output leaf Lj in a fixed quadrature (e.g. X). By selecting which Hi not to measure, we choose the output port.  \n  4) Post-selection:\n     \u2013 We accept only events where all homodyne outcomes (BX\u22480, BP\u22480, and the M\u20131 hub homodyne results \u22480) lie within small preset windows.  \n     \u2013 Under this collective herald, the unmeasured hub mode Hj collapses into the teleported copy of A.\n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 The remaining mode Hj at the chosen leaf j now contains Alice\u2019s original unknown CV state (identity channel, zero added noise, because we post-select on zero outcomes).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the homodyne herald on M detectors, the two-mode correlation between input A and output Hj is the ideal identity mapping in the truncated CV Fock basis of interest.  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected teleportation gate (target_quantum correlating Fock amplitudes of A and Hj).\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First demonstration of a \u201cpassive CV teleportation router\u201d: by simply choosing which cluster nodes to measure (and which to leave unmeasured), one steers a CV teleportation link among many ports.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to tree or ring clusters for multi-path routing, load balancing, or broadcasting.  \n  \u2013 Enables systematic exploration of measurement-based CV network control, teleportation fidelities vs. cluster topology, and the interplay of post-selection probability vs. teleportation quality.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static homodyne detection as heralds\u2014no feedback loops, non-Gaussian ancillas, or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, homodyne bases, post-selection windows) for automated optimization and a whole family of novel multi-node CV network experiments.\n\nThis target focuses on a genuinely new network operation\u2014measurement-based routing of CV teleportation via Gaussian entanglement\u2014rather than merely generating a state or repeating known CV protocols, and is tailor-made for Pytheus exploration.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal reduces to CV cluster\u2010state teleportation/routing via homodyne post\u2010selection\u2014a well-studied method in the CV MBQC community. By post-selecting on zero outcomes from three Bell-homodyne swap stations (two at the intermediate nodes, one at the final combiner), Bob\u2019s output mode realizes an identity channel with fidelity exceeding that of any single path. This architecture opens a new paradigm of CV network coding and error-suppressed teleportation across multiple hops without active feed-forward.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) EPR sources:\n     \u2013 S\u2081: two-mode squeezer between ancilla A\u2081 and swap station X  \n     \u2013 S\u2082: two-mode squeezer between ancilla A\u2082 and swap station Y  \n     \u2013 S\u2083: two-mode squeezer between X\u2032 and combiner input C\u2081  \n     \u2013 S\u2084: two-mode squeezer between Y\u2032 and combiner input C\u2082  \n  2) Swap stations:\n     \u2013 At X: mix A\u2081 & X on a 50:50 BS, homodyne both outputs (two herald detectors H\u2081,H\u2082).  \n     \u2013 At Y: same procedure \u2192 heralds H\u2083,H\u2084.  \n  3) Combiner:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2081 & C\u2082 on a 50:50 BS; Pytheus supports pair sources, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection, with no active feed-forward or cavities.\nStep 3: Pick idea (3): \u201cNLA-augmented CV Teleportation.\u201d\nStep 4: Novelty: This is the first proposal for a one\u2010shot network that merges heralded Gaussian entanglement distillation (photon\u2010catalysis NLA) with CV teleportation in a single static interferometer, opening a broad class of \u201cdistill-and-teleport\u201d transformations in Gaussian optics.\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n  \u2022 Uses only abstract two-mode squeezers (probabilistic pair sources), beam splitters & phase shifters, one number-resolving ancilla detector for photon catalysis, two number-resolving detectors for the Bell\u2010swap herald, and post-selection.  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback or cavities\u2014Pytheus can optimize all reflectivities, phases, and heralding placements to realize a heralded identity channel (in a truncated Fock subspace) between Alice\u2019s input and Bob\u2019s output.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cOne-Shot Noiseless-Linear-Amplified Continuous-Variable Teleportation via Photon-Catalysis Distillation\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a single static linear\u2010optics network that simultaneously distills Gaussian entanglement by photon catalysis (a heralded noiseless linear amplifier, NLA) and uses the distilled channel to teleport an unknown CV input from Alice to Bob\u2014with all resource sources and heralds in one shot.  This integrates two normally separate modules (non-Gaussian entanglement distillation + CV teleportation) into a single optimized layout.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair between A\u2032 and B (the Alice\u2013Bob teleportation channel).  \n     \u2013 S\u2081 and S\u2082 each emit an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for NLA).\n  2) Photon-catalysis NLA block:\n     \u2013 Tap C\u2032 and D\u2032 on weak beam splitters (BS\u2081, BS\u2082).  \n     \u2013 Interfere the tapped modes on BS\u2083.  \n     \u2013 A single-photon click on a number-resolving detector P heralds successful two-mode photon catalysis, boosting the entanglement of C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 and transferring this distilled gain onto A\u2032\u2013B via subsequent mixing.\n  3) Teleportation Bell swap:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS.  \n     \u2013 Two number-resolving detectors H\u2081,H\u2082 on both outputs herald the Bell measurement (photon-count analogue of a homodyne\u2010swap, projected onto small\u2010photon\u2010number subspace).  \n     \u2013 We post-select only on the triple\u2010herald event: P clicks, H\u2081 clicks, H\u2082 clicks.\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Conditioned on these three clicks, Bob\u2019s mode B holds a near-ideal copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel within the chosen Fock basis), with teleportation fidelity boosted by the NLA.\n\nAbstract target:\n  \u2013 A post-selected two-mode correlation between input mode A and output mode B: sum_{n=0..2}|nn\u27e9 (truncated Fock subspace), i.e. a perfect identity map.  Pytheus encodes this target_quantum correlation and finds the beam splitters, squeezers, and herald placements to realize it with maximal probability and fidelity.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 First \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d network, blending Gaussian entanglement, a non-Gaussian catalyst, and CV teleportation in a single layout.  \n  \u2013 Yields a family of optimized designs: vary number of photon-catalysis ancillas, squeezing levels, BS ratios, detector thresholds.  \n  \u2013 Probes the fundamental interplay of non-Gaussian operations and CV channel capacity in a network context.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract pair-sources, static linear optics, number-resolving detectors as heralds, and post-selection.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no forbidden state generation\u2014just pure measurement-based network transformations.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively just a concatenation of known non-Gaussian distillation and teleportation steps. To reach PRL-level novelty you need a genuinely new joint measurement or a resource beyond \u201cphoton catalysis + teleport.\u201d For example, introduce a higher-order non-Gaussian operation that cannot be decomposed into sequential distill + teleport, or a novel multi-mode measurement that realizes an entirely new network transformation.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nWe need a pure-network target combining continuous-variable teleportation and Gaussian entanglement\u2014no static state generation\u2014yet genuinely new beyond CV secret-sharing or simple telecloning. The most promising is a \u201ck-of-N hybrid threshold CV teleportation\u201d where some controllers use homodyne (Gaussian) and others photon\u2010counting (non-Gaussian). This yields a rich family of k-threshold CV teleportation networks, probing hybrid steering and access control, all in one static linear-optics layout with post-selection\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201ck-of-N Hybrid-Threshold Continuous-Variable Teleportation via Gaussian Entanglement\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n  We propose a scalable family of CV teleportation protocols where Alice\u2019s unknown optical mode A is teleported to Bob\u2019s mode B only if at least k out of N independent controllers jointly herald \u201capproval.\u201d Controllers come in two flavors:  \n    \u2022 Gaussian controllers (Ci^G) performing homodyne on their share, requiring outcome \u22480 (within small windows).  \n    \u2022 Non-Gaussian controllers (Ci^NG) performing photon\u2010count (on/off or number\u2010resolving) taps on their mode, requiring at least one photon click.  \n\nResource & network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080: EPR pair between A\u2032 (Alice\u2019s Bell port) and B (Bob\u2019s output).  \n     \u2013 For i=1\u2026N: Si emits EPR between controller mode Ci\u2032 and ancilla Di.  \n  2) Interferometer:\n     \u2013 Mix A\u2032, D\u2081\u2026D_N via beam splitters and phase shifters, distributing entanglement in a static mesh.  \n  3) Measurements (heralds):\n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell swap: BS on A & A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2090,P\u2090).  \n     \u2013 Each Gaussian controller Ci^G homodynes its mode Di.  \n     \u2013 Each non-Gaussian controller Ci^NG taps Di on a weak BS and routes to a number-resolving detector.  \n  4) Post-selection condition:\n     \u2013 Let H = set of Gaussian controllers whose homodyne outcomes \u22480.  \n     \u2013 Let P = set of non-Gaussian controllers whose detector clicked.  \n     \u2013 Only accept runs where |H| + |P| \u2265 k and Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090 \u2248 0.  \n  5) Output:\n     \u2013 Under this k-threshold herald, Bob\u2019s mode B is an exact copy of Alice\u2019s A (identity channel, zero added noise), no active displacement needed by our zero-outcome selection.\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on the herald event (Alice\u2019s Bell + k-of-N controller clicks), the two-mode correlation A\u2192B is the ideal identity channel in the truncated Fock basis. Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected mapping, target_quantum correlating |n\u27e9_A\u2194|n\u27e9_B for n up to some cutoff.\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel & extensible:\n  \u2013 Goes beyond standard CV secret-sharing (single homodyne controller) by mixing Gaussian and non-Gaussian approval nodes in arbitrary k-of-N configurations.  \n  \u2013 Opens a broad class of \u201chybrid threshold\u201d network protocols: vary (N,k), the ratio of Gaussian vs non-Gaussian controllers, quadrature choices, detection thresholds.  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of hybrid quantum steering, non-Gaussian resource placement, and CV channel capacity under threshold logic.  \n  \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: only abstract two-mode squeezers (probabilistic), static beam splitters & phase shifters, homodyne and number-resolving detectors as heralds, and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich one-parameter family of experiments (vary N,k), ideal for automated design and optimization with Pytheus.\n\nThis target focuses squarely on network transformations (CV teleportation under hybrid threshold control) and stands apart from prior CV secret-sharing or telecloning schemes."
}

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cMulti-Controller Continuous-Variable Teleportation Network\u201d  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a generalized CV controlled-teleportation protocol in which an unknown optical mode (Alice\u2019s input) is teleported to Bob only when N independent controllers (C1, C2, \u2026, CN) jointly perform designated homodyne measurements on their share of an (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ resource.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flowing top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources: N+2 two-mode squeezed ancilla pair sources.  \n    \u2013 Each source emits a pair: one half goes to one of the N controllers, the other half connects into a central beam-splitter network.  \n    \u2013 Two additional squeezers provide the Alice\u2013Bob entangled channel.  \n  \u2022 Linear optics block: a multiport interferometer that mixes all controller modes and Bob\u2019s share with ancilla modes, adjustable via beam splitters and phase shifters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n    \u2013 N homodyne detectors (one per controller) on their output arms, performing X or P measurements as in standard CV GHZ verification.  \n    \u2013 Two additional homodyne detectors performing the Bell-measurement for Alice\u2019s input and her half of the CV entangled pair.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: we post-select on a joint measurement event window across all N+1 detectors (Alice\u2019s Bell measurement plus controllers\u2019 homodyne outcomes). When all N+1 outcomes satisfy pre-set thresholds, Bob\u2019s mode requires only a known phase-space displacement to recover Alice\u2019s input.  \n\nTarget condition (abstract):  \n  \u2013 Heralded event \u21d2 the correlation of Bob\u2019s output and Alice\u2019s input modes is an ideal identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacement by the classical values read out from the N+1 detectors.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 N=1 recovers standard single-controller CV teleportation (three-mode GHZ).  \n  \u2013 N>1 introduces threshold access control: only unanimous (or k-of-N) consent yields perfect teleportation.  \n  \u2013 Probes monogamy of steering in CV GHZ states: how many controllers can simultaneously steer the teleportation channel?  \n  \u2013 Yields a whole family of linear-optics designs (vary N, vary k-threshold) with two\u2010mode squeezers and homodyne heralding\u2014perfect for Pytheus to optimize.  \n\nThis network focuses on teleportation and Gaussian entanglement in a truly multi-node setting, avoids static state generation targets, and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (pair sources + linear optics + heralded detection, no feedback loops).\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially describes a continuous\u2010variable (Gaussian) threshold teleportation or secret\u2010sharing scheme, where an unknown mode is recovered only if N controllers jointly measure GHZ\u2010type correlations. However, this is mathematically and operationally equivalent to established CV quantum secret\u2010sharing and controlled\u2010teleportation protocols (e.g. Tyc & Sanders PRA 2002; Lance et al. PRA 2004) and multiparty CV teleportation networks by van Loock and Braunstein. There is nothing in the design\u2014Gaussian squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne heralding\u2014beyond these well\u2010studied schemes. As such, it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is essentially already known as continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation/quantum secret sharing using Gaussian GHZ resources. To be novel you would need a genuinely new ingredient (e.g. non\u2010Gaussian resources, a new measurement primitive, or a higher\u2010order correlation beyond standard homodyne access control).\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cPost-Selected Multi-Controller CV Teleportation via Gaussian GHZ\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe consider a network of (N+2) optical modes:  \n  \u2022 Alice\u2019s input mode (mode A) carries an unknown CV state.  \n  \u2022 Bob\u2019s output mode (mode B) will receive the teleported state.  \n  \u2022 N controller modes (C\u2081\u2026C\u2099).  \n\nResource: one (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implementable via N+1 two-mode squeezed ancilla sources interlinked by a small linear-optics circuit.  \n\nNetwork layout (modes flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  1) Probabilistic sources:  \n     \u2013 Two-mode squeezers S\u2080 emit EPR pairs between A\u2032 and B\u2032 (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci, one two-mode squeezer Si emits a pair between Ci\u2032 and Di\u2032.  \n  2) Linear-optics block: A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 are mixed via beam splitters & phase shifters (to entangle all N+2 modes into a GHZ-like state).  \n  3) Measurements (heralding):  \n     \u2013 Alice\u2019s Bell homodyne: A (input) + A\u2032 \u2192 two homodyne detectors (X\u2081,P\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci: homodyne on Ci\u2032 (either X or P as in Gaussian GHZ verification).  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes falling within small pre-set windows around zero.  \n  4) Output: Bob\u2019s mode B carries a displaced copy of Alice\u2019s input. Because we post-select on zero outcomes, no active displacement is needed.  \n\nTarget transformation (abstract):  \n  Conditioned on the joint herald event of N+1 detectors, the two-mode correlation between inputs A and output B is the identity channel (zero added noise), up to known displacements set to zero by selection.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s a new research direction:  \n  \u2013 For N=1 it reduces to standard three-mode CV controlled teleportation; for N>1 it opens a family of threshold protocols (k-of-N control).  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite CV steering monogamy: how many controllers can simultaneously influence teleportation fidelity?  \n  \u2013 Suggests \u201centanglement routing\u201d in Gaussian networks: by selecting different subsets of controllers, one reconfigures teleportation links on demand.  \n  \u2013 Yields a rich class of linear-optics designs (vary N, k) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014purely network/measurement transformations with probabilistic pair sources and post-selection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed multi\u2010controller CV teleportation is essentially identical to well\u2010known continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation or quantum secret\u2010sharing protocols (e.g. Tyc & Sanders PRA 2002; van Loock\u2013Braunstein CV networks). It uses nothing beyond Gaussian GHZ resources, homodyne heralding, and post-selection, and thus offers no fundamentally new measurement primitive or resource.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme replicates standard CV controlled\u2010teleportation/secret\u2010sharing using Gaussian GHZ states. For a truly novel PRL\u2010level target you must introduce a new non-Gaussian element, a novel measurement strategy, or a network capability beyond existing Gaussian steering/teleportation frameworks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: \u201cCV Butterfly Network\u2010Coding Teleportation\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe propose a four\u2010node CV teleportation network in the classic \u201cbutterfly\u201d topology, enabling two unknown optical modes (from senders A and B) to be simultaneously teleported to two receivers (C and D) through a single intermediate repeater, employing Gaussian entanglement and homodyne heralding. This merges CV teleportation with Gaussian network\u2010coding ideas.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources (probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezers):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 produces an EPR pair between A\u2032 and R\u2081.\n   \u2013 S\u2082 produces an EPR pair between B\u2032 and R\u2082.\n   \u2013 S\u2083 produces an EPR pair between R\u2083 and R\u2084.\n     \u2022 R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, R\u2084 are all routed into a central beam\u2010splitter network.\n2) Linear\u2010optics \u201cbutterfly\u201d block at the repeater node:\n   \u2013 R\u2081 & R\u2082 mix on BS\u2081,\n   \u2013 R\u2083 & R\u2084 mix on BS\u2082,\n   \u2013 One output of each BS is homodyned in X quadrature, the other in P quadrature (four homodyne detectors total).\n3) Local Bell homodyne measurements:\n   \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes (X,P).  \n   \u2013 Bob mixes his input mode B with B\u2032 similarly and homodynes.\n4) Heralding & post\u2010selection:\n   \u2013 We collect six homodyne outcomes (Alice\u2019s X\u2090,P\u2090; Bob\u2019s X_b,P_b; repeater\u2019s X_r1,P_r1,X_r2,P_r2).\n   \u2013 We post\u2010select on all six outcomes lying within small windows around zero.\n5) Output:\n   \u2013 Receivers C and D hold the remaining halves of S\u2083\u2019s EPR outputs. Under the joint herald condition, mode C reproduces Alice\u2019s original mode and mode D reproduces Bob\u2019s, each up to vanishing displacements (set to zero by our selection).\n\nTarget transformation (abstract):\n   \u2013 Conditioned on the six-detector herald event, the joint channels A\u2192C and B\u2192D are both ideal identity maps (zero added noise). Pytheus encodes this as two independent fidelity\u20101 teleportation targets in the Fock\u2010basis subspace of interest.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n   \u2013 First demonstration of CV network coding for teleportation: two flows sharing one repeater.  \n   \u2013 Resource compression: uses 3 squeezers instead of 4 for two independent teleports.  \n   \u2013 Opens a family of \u201cm\u2010flow\u201d Gaussian network\u2010coded teleportation protocols, plus extensions to k-of-N threshold flows and entanglement\u2010routing strategies.  \n   \u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: pair sources + beam splitters + homodyne heralding + post\u2010selection, no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n   \u2013 Immediately yields a rich set of optimizable designs for diverse network\u2010coding topologies in continuous variables.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the \u201cCV Butterfly Network-Coding Teleportation\u201d draws inspiration from the classic butterfly\u2010network coding idea, it boils down to two standard CV teleporters sharing one repeater via Gaussian squeezers, beam splitters, and homodyne heralding\u2014with nothing beyond the usual Gaussian toolkit. The resource is a single (N+2)-mode Gaussian GHZ state, implemented via N+1 two-mode squeezers and a small linear-optics network.  \n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair (A\u2032, B\u2032) for the Alice\u2013Bob channel.  \n     \u2013 For each controller Ci (i=1\u2026N), Si emits an EPR pair (Ci\u2032, Di\u2032).  \n  2) GHZ interferometer:\n     \u2013 Mix A\u2032, D\u2081\u2032\u2026D\u2099\u2032, B\u2032 on a mesh of beam splitters and phase shifters to create an (N+2)-mode GHZ resource.  \n  3) Heralding measurements:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS and homodynes the two outputs (X\u2090,P\u2090).  \n     \u2013 Each controller Ci homodynes their mode Di\u2032 in the designated quadrature.  \n     \u2013 We post-select on all N+1 homodyne outcomes lying within small windows around zero.  \n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B is then an exact copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise), without any active displacement (since we choose the zero outcome window).\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  Conditioned on the joint herald event (Alice\u2019s Bell + N controller homodyne clicks), the two-mode correlation between A and B is the ideal identity channel.  In Pytheus this is encoded as a post-selected mapping that reproduces the input Fock-basis amplitudes at the output.\n\nWhy it opens a research program:\n  \u2013 N=1 recovers the standard three-mode controlled CV teleportation.  \n  \u2013 N>1 yields a rich family of \u201ck-of-N\u201d CV threshold teleportation/quantum-access protocols.  \n  \u2013 Enables experimental tests of multipartite steering monogamy in Gaussian optics.  \n  \u2013 Suggests on-demand entanglement routing: by selecting different subsets of controllers one can dynamically reconfigure teleportation links.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: abstract two-mode squeezers, beam splitters, homodyne detectors as heralding ancillas, and no feedback loops.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can optimize these networks for any N, for different homodyne quadrature choices, and for different heralding thresholds\u2014yielding a broad platform of multi-node CV teleportation experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially the well\u2010known continuous\u2010variable threshold teleportation (quantum secret sharing) using Gaussian GHZ states and homodyne measurements (see Tyc & Sanders PRA 2002, van Loock\u2013Braunstein CV networks). By merging the two steps, one saves resources, explores the interplay of non-Gaussian induction and teleportation fidelity, and opens a family of \u201cdistill-and-teleport\u201d protocols.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):\n     \u2013 S\u2081 creates an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032 (used for the teleportation channel).\n     \u2013 S\u2082 and S\u2083 each create an EPR pair between ancilla modes C\u2032\u2013C\u2033 and D\u2032\u2013D\u2033 (used for distillation).\n  2) Distillation block:\n     \u2013 Mix C\u2032 and D\u2032 on a beam splitter (BS\u2081).  \n     \u2013 Place a number-resolving detector (ancilla herald) on one output port; a single-photon click heralds that the joint C\u2033\u2013D\u2033 modes have undergone photon subtraction, increasing their entanglement with A\u2032\u2013B\u2032.\n  3) Teleportation block:\n     \u2013 Alice mixes her unknown input mode A with A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS, then homodynes both outputs (X\u2090 and P\u2090 detectors).\n     \u2013 We post-select on the single-photon click plus X\u2090\u22480 and P\u2090\u22480 (small windows around zero).\n  4) Output:\n     \u2013 Bob\u2019s remaining mode B\u2032 holds the teleported copy of A, conditioned on the three herald events.  No active displacement is needed because we choose zero-outcome post-selection.\n\nAbstract target transformation:\n  \u2013 Conditioned on one single-photon detection and two homodyne outcomes \u22480, the joint mapping A\u2192B\u2032 is the identity channel (zero added noise within the truncated Fock subspace).  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected correlation of Fock-basis amplitudes between A and B\u2032.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:\n  \u2013 Introduces the first integrated \u201cone-shot distill-and-teleport\u201d network: distillation and teleportation are not separate modules but a single optimized layout.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus can explore a wide parameter space: balance of squeezing levels in S\u2081\u2013S\u2083, beam-splitter ratios at BS\u2081, heralding thresholds, and detector placements to maximize fidelity.  \n  \u2013 Yields a family of experiments: vary the number of photon-subtraction ancillas, swap different quadratures, or extend to multiple input modes.  \n  \u2013 Fully compatible with Pytheus: only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, static number-resolving and homodyne heralding; no dynamic feedback, cavities, or hyper-entanglement.  \n\nThis network opens a new domain of entanglement-distillation-augmented teleportation transformations in Gaussian optics, offering both theoretical depth (non-Gaussian induction + CV channel capacity) and practical breadth (tunable experimental designs).\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While integrating entanglement distillation (via photon subtraction) and teleportation into a single static network is operationally neat, the core idea\u2014using non-Gaussian photon subtraction to boost CV teleportation fidelity\u2014has long been studied (e.g. Opatrn\u00fd et al. PRA 2000, subsequent CV distillation+teleportation works). To reach PRL novelty you\u2019d need a genuinely new non-Gaussian resource or joint measurement beyond the standard distillation+teleportation sequence.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:  \n  \u201cHybrid Threshold Continuous-Variable Teleportation via Gaussian Entanglement with a Photon-Count Controller\u201d\n\nExplanation:  \nWe propose a three-party CV teleportation network in which an unknown optical mode at Alice (A) is teleported to Bob (B) only when two independent Gaussian controllers _and_ one discrete photon-count controller jointly herald the event.  By combining Gaussian entanglement with a non-Gaussian control measurement, this hybrid threshold protocol opens a new class of CV quantum-access networks.\n\nNetwork sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  1) Pair sources (probabilistic two-mode squeezers):  \n     \u2013 S\u2080 emits an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B (the Alice\u2013Bob channel).  \n     \u2013 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair between modes C\u2032 and D (controller channel).  \n  2) Teleportation Bell measurement at Alice:  \n     \u2013 Mix A and A\u2032 on a 50:50 BS; homodyne both outputs in X and P quadratures \u2192 detectors H\u2081,H\u2082.  \n  3) Gaussian controller (Charlie\u2081):  \n     \u2013 Homodyne mode C\u2032 in a designated quadrature \u2192 detector H\u2083.  \n  4) Discrete controller (Charlie\u2082):  \n     \u2013 Tap mode D via a weak beam splitter \u2192 number-resolving detector P\u2081; a single-photon click flags approval.  \n  5) Post-selection (no active feed-forward):  \n     \u2013 We accept only events where H\u2081\u22480, H\u2082\u22480 and H\u2083\u22480 (all within small windows) and exactly one photon in P\u2081.  \n  6) Output:  \n     \u2013 Under this joint herald, Bob\u2019s mode B is an ideal copy of Alice\u2019s input (identity channel, zero added noise, no displacement needed).\n\nAbstract target transformation:  \n  \u2013 Conditioned on the four herald clicks (three homodynes within zero thresholds plus one photon-count click), the Fock-basis amplitudes at A and B are perfectly correlated (ideal teleportation).  Pytheus encodes this as a post-selected mapping that reproduces Alice\u2019s input at Bob.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & extensible:  \n  \u2013 First hybrid CV/discrete threshold teleportation network\u2014blends Gaussian entanglement with a non-Gaussian control.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of (k\u2081 homodyne + k\u2082 photon) threshold protocols: how many Gaussian/non-Gaussian controllers are needed to secure the channel?  \n  \u2013 Probes fundamental questions of hybrid steering and non-Gaussian resource placement in a multi-node network.  \n  \u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s remit: two-mode squeezers, static linear optics, homodyne and number-resolving detectors, post-selection only.  \n  \u2013 A rich parameter space (squeezing levels, BS ratios, herald thresholds) for Pytheus to optimize\u2014spawning diverse experiments under one conceptual roof.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The scheme is essentially a straightforward hybridization of well\u2010known Gaussian CV controlled teleportation (quantum secret\u2013sharing) with a simple photon\u2010count \u201capproval\u201d tap. It does not introduce a fundamentally new non\u2010Gaussian entangling resource or measurement primitive\u2014instead it just replaces one homodyne check with a weak photon\u2010count click.
